DOC.HEAD: Report: Army Overcharged Soldiers, Diverted Money to VIPs
DOC.TEXT: The Army overcharged its personnel for temporary lodging and diverted the money to projects like the renovation of a VIP house and two custom throw rugs costing $3,600, congressional investigators say. The General Accounting Office, in reviewing the daily fees assessed to soldiers staying at special housing during training, found that from 1985 to 1989, two Army commands amassed more than $70 million from inflated charges assessed against the per diem allowance given soldiers. The GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, estimated that the amount could rise to more than $100 million after calculating figures for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30. ``Some Army installations have overcharged soldiers for transient lodgings and ... used the procees to subsidize Morale, Welfare and Recreation activities - officers' clubs, golf courses, arts and crafts facilities and lodging for visitors,'' the GAO said in a report released last week. The agency blamed the problems on the absence of effective controls and inadequate management attention. In one instance, the Army used the additional money to fully renovate a four-bedroom house that serves as distinguished visitors' quarters. Among the costs were about $144,000 for customized furnishings, drapes and carpets, including two throw rugs that totaled $3,600. The Army installation also planned to spend about $272,000 for special stationery and landscaping but when questioned by the GAO, it lowered its cost projections to $81,600. The GAO did not specify at which installation the renovation occurred, but its study examined domestic facilities. The agency said the Training and Doctrine Command and Forces Command accumulated the inflated charges. The money comes from the billions of dollars the Army spends each year to train its personnel, with a portion for the per diem paid to soldiers undergoing training. In another case, the GAO found that a large office space in transient quarters was converted into an exercise room with equipment even though a fully equipped gym was across the street. ``According to installation officials, the exercise room was provided to meet commercial hotel standards and to ensure that guests were not inconvenienced,'' the GAO said. In a response included in the report, the Defense Department said it has taken steps to review and correct the problems identified by the GAO. It said it also is studying current transient housing policies. ``It should be noted that the identified problems occurred during a period of major policy transition in which the department adopted practices to operate nonappropriated fund programs and facilities in a businesslike manner,'' said Christopher Jehn, assistant secretary of defense for force management and personnel. The GAO also found that the Army paid for more expensive off-base lodgings for personnel when there were vacancies at the designated transient quarters. During one month at an installation, the lodging office authorized off-base per diem for 146 personnel for a total of 1,939 days. But during the same period, 206 reservations were canceled or never claimed, amounting to 5,040 days available to house personnel. The GAO recommended that the overcharges be returned either to the original appropriations or to the U.S. Treasury. The Pentagon, which generally agreed with the GAO's suggestions, did not concur on returning the money. The Defense Department proposed disbursing the money based on a department legal interpretation of the issue. Rep. John Murtha, D-Pa., chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on defense, requested the report.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Shield Reservists Pay Price For Confronting Saddam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: Laserphoto DHA1 Nov. 12
DOC.TEXT: Without complaint, George Phelan left his family and his law practice to do his military duty as a reservist in Operation Desert Shield. He missed the first birthday of his daughter, Asia, Nov. 6. He celebrated his 40th birthday Sept. 4 at gas mask school with his army buddies at Fort Devens, Mass. His father's handling mortgage payments and monthly bills because Phelan's Japanese-born wife's English isn't good enough to take care of things. Before he left for active duty, Phelan had two days to find another lawyer to handle his pending cases. He didn't have time to tell all his clients he was leaving, so he wrote them letters and took out a newspaper ad saying he'd be away for an indefinite time. And the switch from civilian to military pay has meant a substantial cut in income. But despite all the disruptions, you won't hear any gripes from Phelan, of Fall River, Mass. ``When your country calls you to defend it and defend its interests, I think it's a small sacrifice to pay,'' said Phelan, a U.S. Army major in the 46th Judge Advocate-General's detachment in Saudi Arabia, the first reserve unit activated in the Persian Gulf crisis. ``It's my duty to be here. You've got to put the inconvenience aside and put your mind to your work,'' he said. ``As simplistic and naive as it might sound, I'm proud to be over here.'' The call-up is the first of reservists and National Guard in 20 years, and the largest since the 1950-53 Korean War. More than 34,000 citizen-soldiers have been called to active duty for a minimum of 90 days. More will follow under President Bush's announcement that up to 150,000 reinforcements will join the 230,000 American troops confronting Saddam Hussein following his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Like Phelan, the reservists were plucked from the civilian life as part of their military obligation. ``It's something you've got to be willing to do even though it might be unexpected and certainly inconvenient from a business and personal point of view,'' the soft-spoken Phelan said. He left the modest ranch home he bought last year to sleep on a cot in a tent pieced together with ponchos, shelter halves and plywood boards. Instead of lawyerly blue suits, he wears desert camouflage fatigues. Instead of handling civilian cases, he advises military commanders on disciplinary matters. ``The money part's going to hurt, but you can always make the money up in the long run,'' Phelan said. He admitted tht ``the longer I'm away from the practice the more difficult it'll be to revive when I get home.'' But he stressed: ``The thing that eats at me is not being able to enjoy things I'll never be able to recapture, like my daughter's first birthday. The first teeth, walking for the first time, saying her first words - those things you can't get back because they only happen one time.'' Back home, Phelan had more than 500 clients a year in his one-man law practice. He also provided legal services to about 500 elderly people. He's only had one contact with the attorney now handling his cases. And it would be impossible to run his affairs while soldiering in Saudi Arabia. For the most part, reservists are putting their hardships aside. ``We obviously had to do some juggling,'' said Col. Kevin Murphy, 44, of Hanover, Mass., who's also a reservist lawyer specializing in financial planning. ``We're making sacrifices, but it's something we're doing willingly.'' For people used to the freedoms of civilian life, they've had to adapt to communal showers, waiting in line at smelly latrines, eating military chow and taking what spartan-like recreation they can. The physical discomforts can be overcome. What affects them most is what's missing in their personal lives. ``The biggest battle is within ourselves, keeping our minds right,'' said Staff Sgt. Paul Boyd, 37, of Murfreesboro, Tenn., a National Guardsman assigned to the 130th Rear Area Operations Center. ``One of the things I've learned here is what's important. It's not a house, a boat, a car. None of the material things mean anything. It's my loved ones that count,'' he said. ``I despise the United States Army. It's the most screwed up, disorganized organization I've even been associated with.'' National Guard Sgt. Gerald McCormick's wife is expecting their first child in December. Missing the birth is more of a loss than the financial consequences of switching from being a financial planner to a soldier. ``It's just lost time you won't ever make up,'' said McCormick of Nashville, Tenn. When he gets home, he said, ``I'll never complain about living conditions again.''

DOC.HEAD: Vietnamese-Born German: Stranger in a Familiar Land
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMsreport.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Firing the Women
DOC.TEXT: His passport says he is a citizen of Germany. He speaks its language with perfect fluency and has a law degree from one of its finest universities. His wife and two children are German. But one day, Vu Dinh Nimh went to an unemployment agency to see about a job. He said the man at the reception desk directed him to a special section for foreigners. ``Second floor,'' the man said. ``But I'm German,'' Vu told the man. ``You're not German,'' the man said. ``You don't even belong here. Why don't you go back where you came from?'' So Vu went back to where he came from, back to his soot-covered tenement, back to his a rundown neighborhood, back to his family in their cramped apartment in the capital of the new Germany. Vu is a Vietnamese native who came here in 1974 to study at East Berlin's prestigious Humboldt University and fell in love with a German woman who worked in the math department. He's also one of thousands of foreign-born residents who believe they are being shut out of the former nation's job market as it struggles to adapt to a free market. About 95,000 Vietnamese, Mozambicans and Cubans worked in the country under contracts made with their countries by the old Communist government of what was East Germany. Gabriela Endert-Reinhart, a spokeswoman for the employment office in Berlin, said there were no statistics on how many of them are still working, but most have left the country and many of those remaining are jobless. ``It's Germany's shame that people we invited here to work are being unfairly fired,'' she said. Most the the guest workers, about 60,000, are Vietnamese. About 3,800 of the 4,600 in eastern Berlin have lost their jobs, said Tran Manh Tuan, Vietnamese diplomatic attache in Berlin. Foreigners have become victims of violent attacks and increasing hostility in eastern Germany, a situation blamed in large part on the dire economic situation. Vu had to go back to Vietnam when he completed his education in 1979, but came back three years later as a guest worker in a factory. He married his college sweetheart, Jutta Kerger, and the couple built a life. He eventually got a decent job as a translator for 200 Vietnamese workers at the Gold Point shoe factory in Berlin. In August, however, those workers were let go. Vu said he has had no success finding work and doesn't expect to. The family has applied for permission to immigrate to Canada. The couple and their two children - 3-year-old Martin and Emily, 6 - live in the drab Lichtenberg district of Berlin. Recently, Vu said he took Emily to her school and a group of high school students nearby shouted racial and anti-foreigner epithets. ``They said, `Today we'll let you live, but next time we'll kill you,''' recalled Vu, 37. Another time, he took Martin to a grocery store to buy bread. A group of neo-Nazi skinheads loitering outside refused to let them enter. ``There never used to be problems before the economic situation got worse,'' Vu says. ``I could say `good day' to people on the street and they would say `good day' back.'' In the family's neat, clean, tiny two-room apartment, the door has a sticker - a red maple leaf, the symbol of Canada. They think of Canada as a land tolerant of foreigners and mixed marriages, a place with no barriers to employment for smart, competent people. They live three doors down from the house where Jutta lived as a child, a neighborhood where they could once stroll together. Now, they can't wait to leave.

DOC.HEAD: Dog's Tail Apparently Starts House Fire
DOC.TEXT: A fire that destroyed a house Tuesday apparently started when a 3-year-old boy set his pet dog on fire with a cigarette lighter, fire officials said. District Fire Chief Paul Hemmeter said the boy told a paramedic at the scene what happened. ``The little boy told her ... `Toto was bad. Toto bit me. I set fire to Toto's tail,''' Hemmeter said. The boy, his grandmother and two other children were in the house when the fire started shortly after midnight. All escaped without serious injury, he said. The small, long-haired dog was not found. Hemmeter said he believes the pet died in the fire. Hemmeter said the grandmother had fallen asleep on a couch while watching television when the boy apparently used a cigarette lighter to set the dog's tail on fire. ``It's possible that the boy simply set fire to the bedclothes as he was setting fire to the dog,'' Hemmeter said. ``But from the amount of fire they had, the dog probably ran from place to place setting fires.'' He said all the evidence supports the boy's version of how the fire started and no family members contradicted his account.

DOC.HEAD: Closing Arguments Made in Arsenic Poisoning Trial
LaserPhoto GB1
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) - A woman charged in the 1986 arsenic-poisoning death of her boyfriend administered repeated doses of the poison to her two husbands, one of whom died, a prosecutor charged Monday. In closing arguments, the defense said the state had failed to prove that Blanche Taylor Moore killed her boyfriend, Raymond Reid. Mrs. Moore, 57, is on trial for first-degree murder in the death of Raymond Reid. She also is charged in the death of her first husband, James Taylor, in 1973 and with two counts of assault in the near lethal arsenic poisoning last year of her now-estranged husband, the Rev. Dwight Moore. She will be tried on those charges later. Prosecutors used those poisonings in the four-week trial in an effort to establish a pattern that pointed to Mrs. Moore. ``When you combine all the evidence, what hits you directly in the face? Forsyth County District Attorney Warren Sparrow asked the jury. ``There was arsenic in Mr. Taylor ... repeatedly administered,'' Sparrow said. ``What about Dwight Moore? The same thing. The fundamental picture is repeated doses of arsenic. ``This is not circumstantial, this is direct and powerful scientific evidence that points unerringly at the defendant,'' he said. Prosecutors have said they will ask for the death penalty if Mrs. Moore is convicted. Defense attorney David Tamer said the state's case was nothing more than circumstantial, saying that at no point did any witness testify about a specific time when Mrs. Moore poisoned Reid. ``The issue in this case is to identify the person who is responsible,'' Tamer said. ``That question is the one on which this case turns. Just because they had elevated arsenic levels does not identify her as the perpetrator.'' Mrs. Moore testified last week that she didn't poison Reid and lovingly cared for him during his stay in hospital before he died. ``I know arsenic was found in these three people, but I know that I didn't do it,'' she said. ``I've never physically harmed other people. To physically harm a person, no, I did not do that.'' Defense attorneys say the real attacker confessed his crime in a letter to Mrs. Moore. Handwriting experts differed over whether the letter could have been written by Mrs. Moore or who defense attorneys say penned it - deceased acquaintance Garvin Thomas.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Militia: How Much of a Threat? ^Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
LaserPhoto AMM4 Nov. 12.
DOC.TEXT: The military instructor stabbed the dummy in the heart with a commando knife, and snapped at a group of Iraqi Popular Army recruits: ``This is your weapon to kill.'' One by one, the men dressed in camouflage fatigues lined up and stabbed the dummy in what was supposed to be hand-to-hand combat training at a suburban Baghdad soccer ground. After Iraq's million-member regular army, these men and women are Saddam Hussein's second line of defense in the confrontation with the U.S.-dominated multinational force. Every day, the Iraqi authorities organize marches through Baghdad and other cities by Popular Army recruits, among them elderly, gray-haired men and gun-toting women, some with heads covered by scarves in the Islamic tradition. Teen-age boys clutch rocket-propelled grenade launchers and chant: ``Down, Down, Bush!'' Iraqi officials boast that 8 million men and women have volunteered for the Popular Army in a wave of patriotic fervor supposedly sparked by Saddam's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But Western and Asian military experts in Iraq estimate that the force's strength is probably closer to 600,000 personnel, a 25 percent increase over its pre-invasion numbers. ``We train on all weapons, but the emphasis is on close-combat weapons and hand-to-hand fighting,'' said Abdul Amin Jamil, one of the instructors. ``My son's in the army and I'm getting trained so that I can fight alongside him,'' said 51-year-old Karim Ali, holding an AK-47 assault rifle in one hand and patting a dagger hanging from his webbing belt. ``I may be needed to defend my country,'' said Fersan Hamid, a 15-year-old schoolboy. ``I'm willing to go to Kuwait and fight.'' Officials claim the volunteers reported to be flocking to join the militia include Palestinians, Egyptians, Syrians, Sudanese and other Arabs. State TV regularly shows zealous recruits chanting undying allegiance to Saddam and military officials handing out guns to young and old to defend the republic. Diplomats question how far the average Iraqi is prepared to go to defend a government as repressive as Saddam's. Still, the Popular Army is everywhere, guarding banks, embassies, hotels and government buildings. With the prospect of war looming, the militia is reported to have been deployed in some numbers across Kuwait, occupying abandoned homes and government buildings. Popular Army cadres are trained for two months - two hours a day, five days a week - in light weapons, anti-tank weapons and anti-aircraft guns. After training, each recruit is given a firearm and allowed to keep it. They are required to report to their bases every week to determine if they're needed for active duty. The militia was initially formed by Saddam in 1970 as the paramilitary wing of the ruling Baath Arab Socialist Party. Its main function was to act as an ideological counterweight to the army to prevent any attempt at a military coup. Led by one of Saddam's closest associates, Deputy Prime Minister Taha Yassin Ramadan, the well-armed militia has been responsible for guarding the political leadership. From an original strength of around 3,000, the Popular Army swelled to around 450,000, including 40,000 women, during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. It was deployed at the front and suffered heavy casualties. Some 10,000 men were captured. During the Iran-Iraq war, the Iraqi regular forces often resented having the less experienced militiamen deployed alongside them. Western diplomats and Western military experts still doubt the Popular Army's fighting abilities, but some Asian diplomats believe that the Popular Army cadres could put up a fight if necessary.

DOC.HEAD: Leaner USDA Select Beef Reaching Supermarkets
DOC.TEXT: Meat researchers have developed a new grade of beef with half the fat of the usual cuts that may be quite appealing to consumers watching their calories and cholesterol. Supermarkets are starting to carry meat labeled USDA Select that has 40 percent to 55 percent less fat than completely trimmed, well-marbled meat graded USDA Choice, said Dr. Larry Cundiff, a genetics expert at the Agriculture Department's Meat and Animal Research Center. ``USDA Select beef contains about 40 calories per ounce compared with 43 to 50 calories for USDA Choice beef,'' said Cundiff. ``This resembles the difference between regular and 2 percent low-fat milk in the dairy case.'' He said scientists have been working for 20 years to characterize breeds of cattle for leanness, tenderness, juiciness and flavor of the meat. The search for leaner beef led to crossbreeding Hereford and Angus breeds with 24 European breeds known for their leanness. Butchers at two large supermarket chains in the Washington, D.C. area said that Select cuts are not as tasty or tender as Choice, but are less expensive. Chef Gus, at Blackie's House of Beef restaurant in Washington, said he wouldn't serve Select beef. ``This is very lean meat. A different texture,'' he said. ``You have to chew it a very long time.'' Cundiff and his colleagues, whose lab is at Clay Center, Neb., have worked to identify breeds or breed crosses that help improve tenderness while reducing fat. ``Piedmontese cattle are an Italian breed with 11.5 percent more lean meat than Hereford and Angus,'' said Cundiff. ``Their offspring produce lean, exceptionally tender meat.'' He said about 40 percent of U.S. cattle already have at least some of the genetic makeup of the newer European breeds. The Clay Center lab keeps about 200 animals of each European breed, including British, Continental and South Asian cattle, for its research. ``We believe that our research has helped the industry produce leaner beef,'' said Cundiff. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Household liquid detergents and cooking oils are being recommended by Agriculture Department researchers as low-cost, extremely effective killers of garden pests. ``This is great stuff for the homeowner,'' said Dr. Thomas Henneberry, a USDA insect expert. ``It's completely non-toxic and simple to mix up. It's as effective as an insecticide.'' He said it may be even more effective than chemicals because many pests have developed a resistance to such sprays. ``We can mix up a gallon of this home brew for less than 30 cents,'' said Dr. George Butler, one of Henneberry's colleagues. ``Commercial insecticide mixes for the homeowner can cost at least $1 a gallon. And we have a pest spray that is environmentally clean.'' Henneberry and Butler said their detergent-oil mix has been effective against ``some of the worst insects and mites,'' including aphids, whiteflies and spider mites. The scientists say homeowners should mix one tablespoon of dishwashing detergent and one cup of oil - either peanut, safflower, corn, soybean or sunflower. When ready to use, mix one to 2{ teaspoons of the prepared solution to one cup of water. Then spray on infested plants using a pump sprayer like the one on a bottle of window cleaner. The researchers have used the mixture successfully on eggplant, carrots, lettuce, Swiss chard, celery, watermelon, pepper and cucumber. ``We found the only disadvantage is that squash, cauliflower and red cabbage are sometimes hurt,'' Butler said. ``The oil may burn the tender leaves of these plants.'' The oils are toxic to insects, while the dishwashing detergent acts as an emulsifier, making the mixture adhere more readily to the plant. ``The key to control is getting the oil-detergent mixture on the insects,'' said Henneberry. ``Usually, these common pests seek protection from the sun and wind by hiding under plant leaves. Be careful to spray all leaf and stem surfaces with a light coat.'' He recommended checking again about one week to 10 days after an application.

DOC.HEAD: Social Security Now Off-Limits for Future Budget Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Advocates for the elderly are claiming a big victory because new budget rules make the $265 billion Social Security system virtually untouchable in future efforts to reduce the federal deficit. The change has critics complaining that it makes little sense to exempt the government's single biggest domestic program from future attempts to narrow the budget shortfall. But it is a relief for more than 39 million elderly, handicapped and other Americans who get monthly checks from the program - and for politicians loath to cut the politically popular pension system. ``It's an important victory,'' said spokesman Bill Ritz of the National Committee to Preserve Social Security and Medicare, which lobbies for senior citizens. In federal budget politics, removing one program from possible cuts simply means that other areas are exposed to potentially deeper reductions. As a result, some defenders of other programs are upset by the favorable treatment for Social Security. ``Whether they're elderly or children, if they're poor, they're poor,'' said Susan Rees, executive director of the Coalition on Human Needs, a Washington-based group that champions aid for low-income Americans of all ages. ``Why should one have to sacrifice for the other?'' As part of their budget deal last month, the Bush administration and congressional leaders agreed to take Social Security out of the calculations used to determine the federal deficit. Proponents said with the pension program running an annual surplus of tens of billions of dollars, the overall budget gap was being shrunk artificially under the old system. That sounds like a dry accounting change, but it's not. What it really means is there is no longer any reason to look to Social Security for budget savings because cutting the program won't make the pool of red ink any smaller. Groups working for the elderly had been pressing lawmakers to make the change for years. They argued that since Social Security pays for itself by payroll tax deductions, it has nothing to do with the burgeoning federal deficit and thus should not be asked to help solve that problem. ``What's the rationale for keeping it in there, other than trying to dodge difficult choices elsewhere in the budget,'' said Martin Corry, director of federal affairs for the American Association of Retired Persons, the nation's biggest organization for seniors. Social Security benefits average $571 a month this year and will climb to $602 on Jan. 1 when a 5.4 percent inflation adjustment takes effect. ``Those are earned benefits,'' Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., chairman of the Senate Finance Social Security subcommittee, said last week. ``That's not the government's money.'' In political terms, cutting Social Security has been off-limits for years because the elderly have proven they are a voting bloc to be reckoned with. That lesson was driven home dramatically a few years ago. In 1985, the Senate's majority Republicans agreed with the White House to a deficit-reduction plan that included a freeze in Social Security's annual inflation increase. The Senate adopted the proposal, 50-49, with the deciding vote cast by then-Vice President George Bush. Two months later, President Reagan backed away from the measure after Democrats agreed to allow higher defense spending. That left Republican lawmakers in an awkward position they soon paid for: when the 1986 election was over, the GOP had lost control of the Senate and has yet to regain it. Ever since, budget writers have been reluctant to even consider reining in Social Security costs. Because of that, some activists say the new budget process means little. ``Congress wasn't going to cut Social Security, and taking it out of the budget calculations was just one more symbolic way to show it's politically untouchable,'' said Marsha Simon, legislative director for Families USA, a lobbying organization for the elderly. The government spent $246 billion on Social Security in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 - 19.9 percent of the entire $1.24 trillion federal budget. The only budget component that was bigger was defense, at $297 billion. The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office, which studies budget issues for Congress, projects Social Security spending to grow by about 7 percent a year, reaching $265 billion this fiscal year and $334 billion by 1995.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan's Nuclear Program is Threatening to Rupture Ties to U.S.
DOC.TEXT: With the fear of Soviet aggression no longer serving as glue, the U.S.-Pakistan relationship is threatening to come apart under the strain of frictions over Pakistan's nuclear program, diplomats say. Congress and the new government of Pakistan appear ready to walk away from the four-decades-old relationship that served as a cornerstone of U.S. policy in South Asia and gave Washington an important friend in the Moslem world. In October, the United States demanded that Islamabad reverse its nuclear program and froze $573 million of economic and military assistance to Pakistan, part of a six-year, $4-billion aid package begun in 1987. After winning elections last month by capitalizing on growing resentment of U.S. influence in this Moslem country of 110 million, President Ghulam Ishaq Khan and his right-wing coalition have declared they can do without U.S. aid. ``We should tighten our belts. We should learn to run our hands deep into our own pockets instead of stretching them before others,'' Ishaq Khan said in a strident state-of-the-union address last week. ``No matter how important foreign aid is we shall not compromise our independence and our freedom for it. We may be poor but we highly cherish our national honor and dignity,'' he said. Ishaq Khan is expected to meet with Vice President Dan Quayle in Japan this week to discuss the nuclear issue and American aid. But analysts and diplomatic sources doubt Pakistan will be able to adequately reassure Washington. ``Although a few screws may be missing or bolts left to tighten, the United States is convinced that Pakistan has the bomb,'' said one diplomatic source, insisting he not be identified further. Pakistan is the third-largest receipient of U.S. aid behind Egypt and Israel, and the benefits are easily recognizable in a country relatively free of the daunting poverty that plagues much of the subcontinent. But before assistance is granted, President Bush must certify to Congress that Pakistan neither possesses nor is building nuclear weapons. For more than a decade, the United States found reasons to look the other way as evidence mounted that Pakistan was moving closer to becoming a nuclear power. That was particularly true at the height of the war in neighboring Afghanistan. Determined to keep Pakistan away from Soviet influence, and beholden to Islamabad for funneling hundreds of millions of dollars in arms to the Moslem resistance, Washington managed to secure certification. But in December 1988, diplomatic sources say, Pakistan was warned to hold its nuclear program in check. ``Early this year their assurances no longer held up,'' said one Western diplomat, also speaking on condition of anonymity. Diplomatic sources say Pakistan crossed the nuclear threshhold when relations with neighboring India began to deteriorate. There have been fears in recent months that the two traditionally hostile neighbors would go to war for a third time over Kashmir, the disputed mountain territory claimed by both. India exploded a nuclear device in 1974, and neither country has agreed to sign the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, which would require them to open their facilities to periodic inspections. Washington's decision to freeze aid, coming on the eve of national elections, embittered Pakistanis and fueled criticism of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, who was overwhelmingly defeated in the Oct. 24 parliamentary vote. Most thought the anti-American rhetoric would subside after the elections, but it has persisted. Pakistan's strategic importance to the United States has diminished with the thaw in the Cold War and the winding down of the war in Afghanistan. And with greater demands for U.S. assistance among the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe, diplomats say, the current aid level to Pakistan cannot be sustained. But others contend the United States cannot afford to lose a friend that served as the front-line state in the fight against Soviet communism, the window to Iran following the 1979 revolution and an intermediary that helped Washington open the door to China. ``The United States doesn't have a lot of friends in the Moslem world,'' said an Arab diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``While the Soviet threat is gone, there are other alliances that Pakistan could enter that would not be in the U.S.' best interests. Washington may yet again discover that a once-loyal friend has become one of its worst enemies.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker to Meet with Canadian Leader on Gulf
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III is making a hastily arranged visit to Bermuda for talks with Canadian External Affairs Minister Joe Clark on resolving the Persian Gulf crisis. Canada has dispatched more than a dozen jet fighters to the gulf in support of the U.S.-led multinational effort there, and it has not ruled out the possibility of sending ground forces. It was not clear, however, whether today's talks would touch on a possible increase in the Canadian military contribution. ``The whole purpose of meeting is to get them together so they have a chance to discuss face-to-face Baker's view of the situation and our view of the situation,'' said Abbe Dann, Clark's spokeswoman. Baker met last week with the other four members of the United Nations Security Council during his swing through Europe and the Middle East. He decided only last Saturday that a consultation with Clark would be useful. Clark was expected to reaffirm Canada's view that Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait - the same view that Baker heard last week in his talks with leaders from the Soviet Union, China, Britain, France, Turkey, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and the exiled Kuwaiti regime. But the majority view among those Baker sounded out was that more time is needed to give diplomacy a chance to work before the military option against Iraq is seriously considered. Bush last week ordered 200,000 more American troops to the gulf to supplement the 230,000 already there. Bermuda was chosen as the site for today's meeting because Clark is en route to Europe and the Middle East for discussions on the gulf situation. He was to leave Bermuda for London at midday after a 90-minute discussion with Baker at the residence of the U.S. consul general. After a luncheon in Bermuda with local officials, Baker planned a mid-afternoon return to Washington to take part in a meeting between President Bush and Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Says Panhandlers Should Pay to Beg
LaserPhoto HAG1
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Anthony Senecal has his hand out to panhandlers, hoping a proposed $50-a-year licensing fee will persuade them to move on. ``I've always been appalled that people who come downtown to shop are always being asked, `Have you got 25 cents? Have you got 50 cents?''' Senecal said. ``That's bull. It isn't right. Pretty soon they're going to stop coming downtown to shop.'' Senecal wants to require panhandlers to buy a $25 license every six months. Violators could get a $500 fine and 10 days in jail. City Council is scheduled to consider the ordinance Thursday. James Tobin, 63, who says he ``panhandles some,'' doubted the ordinance would do much good. ``I panhandle when I go broke,'' he said. ``I guess I'll buy a license if I have to, but it ain't right. It just ain't right.'' Robert O'Brien, spokesman for the state chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, called the proposal preposterous and said the group may challenge it. Robert Bastress, an expert in constitutional law at West Virginia University, said panhandling is a form of commercial speech. ``The Supreme Court has recognized that commercial speech is entitled to some protection under the Constitution, not as much as other forms of speech, perhaps, but some protection,'' he said. The idea came to the mayor after three men asked him for money during the three-block walk from his tobacco shop to City Hall. ``We can't afford having people on the street giving people who come downtown the bum's rush,'' Senecal said. ``Some of these guys get right up in your face if you refuse.'' O'Brien said the ordinance won't solve the problem. ``Winos are going to take their government check, spend $25 on a license and then panhandle freely,'' he said. ``But the guy who has been living in Washington, D.C., and is moving back to Ohio, and runs out of gas, and needs to panhandle to get enough money to get home is the guy who is going to get arrested.'' Senecal said the ordinance isn't aimed at the working poor. He said the Salvation Army's bell-ringers and other charities also would be exempt. ``What I'm after are the winos who make a good living off government checks and beg for money the final two weeks of every month after they blow all their government money,'' Senecal said. One supporter of the measure is the Rev. Bill Crowe, who operates Union Rescue Mission in Martinsburg, a growing town of more than 13,000 just over an hour's drive from Washington. The town has a 2 percent jobless rate, but its homeless shelter usually is full and 39 of the 52 beds at the mission were occupied on a recent night, Crowe said. ``There's no reason for anyone in Martinsburg to bum money or meals or anything else,'' Crowe said. ``We serve meals 24 hours a day, seven days a week. These people are just living off the bottle. They just drink and drink and drink and then start panhandling to get more money.'' Senecal said he doesn't know if his plan would work in big cities like Los Angeles, Detroit and New York. ``The biggest difference between us and New York City is we know all our bums,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Rights Abuses Persist In El Salvador Since Jesuit Slayings
DOC.TEXT: One year after Salvadoran soldiers slaughtered six Jesuit priests, a U.N. human rights expert says abuses ranging from torture to executions persist in the Central American nation. But the report cites a general decline in killings during the first eight months of 1990, with the exception of government-backed death squad activity. ``Thus far in 1990, government action against humanitarian, trade union, peasants and other organizations has continued,'' said Jose Antonio Pastor, a university professor from Spain who compiled the report. Pastor added he ``continued to receive information about harassment of religious organizations and workers by the authorities.'' The report, issued Monday, blames both the U.S.-backed conservative government of President Alfredo Cristiani and the leftist rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front for the persistent violence. But it indicates that both groups have sought to improve the human rights situation. At least 72,000 people have been killed have been killed in the 11-year-old civil war. The government has cut back on summary killings since signing the San Jose Agreement on Human Rights on July 26, and FMLN assassinations of suspected collaborators ceased after that date, the report says. The report notes 40 politically motivated summary executions of civilians by soldiers or other security forces from January to August, compared with 51 in the same period in 1989, citing figures from the Archdiocesan Legal Protection Office. The office, however, counted 46 assassinations by death squads in the period, compared with 17 slayings in the same months of 1989. The Salvadoran government's Human Rights Commission reported 42 summary killings in the first eight months of 1990, compared with 68 in the same months of 1989. The government did not keep figures on death squad activity. For the FMLN, the church counted 12 assassinations from January to August 1990, compared with 30 during those months in 1989. The government counted 49 in the period, compared with 173 in the first eight months of 1989. The government has been severely criticized since soldiers killed six Jesuit priests, their cook and her daughter on Nov. 16, 1989, a day after the beginning of a guerrilla offensive in the capital that left 2,000 dead. Bringing the soldiers and their commanders to justice makes the massacre ``a test case for the credibility of efforts to bring about judicial reform in the country,'' Pastor wrote. ``There seems to be a lack of cooperation on the part of the armed forces, which has gone so far as the destruction of important evidence,'' said the report, referring to the loss of an officer's notes made the night of the killings. Right-wing elements of the military and government view the Roman Catholic Church's advocacy of human rights and social justice as a legal adjunct to the rebel effort. Since the assassination of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero during a Mass in 1980, death squads and rightists have often targeted the clergy. ``Cases of politically motivated disappearances of individuals continue to be reported,'' Pastor added. He said both death squads and the guerrillas were probably responsible for the disappearances. Pastor also found torture of prisoners continued, with the worst treatment given to those from political organizations or unions. Some of the common abuses included ``long periods of interrogation while being blindfolded and without being able to sit down or relieve themselves, extensive beatings, the occasional use of a hood which impedes breathing and causes fainting, immersion of the head in tanks of water, electric shocks and threats to themselves or their families.'' ``Witnesses who did not belong to organizations complained only of intense interrogation while blindfolded,'' he added. Pastor also said there have been reports of harassment of priests, monks and nuns.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators: Milken May Have Made $1 Billion More Than Disclosed
DOC.TEXT: Former junk bond financier Michael Milken - once paid $550 million in a single year by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. - may have received an additional $1 billion during the 1980s, congressional investigators say. Information from the General Accounting Office indicates that about 30 limited partnerships Milken formed with other Drexel employees paid out as much as $2 billion between 1981 and 1989, a House subcommittee staffer said Monday, confirming earlier published reports. As much as $1 billion of the money went to Milken himself, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. There was no indication how much of that amount was actual profit, and the amount attributed to Milken was only an estimate based on larger sums paid out by the partnerships. Milken's sentencing in a massive Wall Street fraud case is expected to be scheduled soon. He could be sentenced up to 28 years in prison. One of the nation's richest men, Milkin already has paid a record $600 million in penalties. He pleaded guilty in April to six felonies, including conspiracy, securities violations and tax fraud for his role in the Wall Street scandals of the 1980s. The House source also said convicted stock speculator Ivan F. Boesky testified behind closed doors in August to the investigations subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee about his dealings with Milken. Boesky, once a leading speculator in the stock of potential takeover targets, paid $100 million to settle insider-trading charges, pleaded guilty to one felony and was sentenced to a three-year prison term, which he has completed. Drexel settled criminal and civil charges in 1988 by agreeing to pay a record $650 million in penalties, as well as pleading guilty to six felony charges. The firm filed for bankruptcy reorganization in February. The House subcommittee has been investigating hundreds of Milken-created Drexel partnerships for several years, but no evidence of illegal activity has been presented. Drexel ended the practice shortly after it came to light two years ago. A spokesman for Milken declined comment on the matter. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the investigations panel and the full Energy and Commerce Committee, wants Milken to testify after his sentencing about trading accounts owned by the limited partnerships he formed with Drexel co-workers, family members and friends. Milken invoked his Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination when he was called to testify before the subcommittee two years ago. Dingell asked the GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, to look into the partnerships. The partnerships bought up large amounts of junk bond issues before they were made available to the general public. Critics say the activity drove up the price of those issues at the expense of Drexel customers, but there has been no final determination of the activity's legality. Federal prosecutors revealed that Drexel paid Milken, mastermind of the firm's rise to prominence in the high-yield, high-risk junk bond business, a total of $1.1 billion between 1984 and 1987, including $550 million the final year. That $550 million paycheck put him the Guinness Book of World Records. The GAO's information consisted of a list of 30 limited partnerships and the total amount each distributed to investors during the 1980s. But it did not specify individual investors or indicate how much of the payouts were profit above the initial investment. The subcommittee source said investigators knew from court documents what percentage was held in the partnerships by major players in the Drexel scandal. ``It gives you a pretty good road map in terms of who was involved in what,'' the source said.
