DOC.HEAD: Atlantis' Countdown Proceeding Smoothly, Weather a Concern
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with new countdown and weather information. Pickup 7th graf pvs, `The mission ...'
DOC.TEXT: The countdown toward Thursday's liftoff of Atlantis with a spy satellite proceeded smoothly despite mounting concerns over launch day weather, NASA said today. The five-member, all-military crew was due to arrive at Kennedy Space Center this afternoon from Johnson Space Center in Houston. Atlantis blasts off sometime between 6:30 p.m. and 10:30 p.m. EST in NASA's fifth night launch of a shuttle. Because the Pentagon flight is secret, the exact time will not be announced until nine minutes before liftoff. The mission is expected to last about four days, during which the crew will deploy a satellite that reportedly will spy on Iraq. NASA spokesman George Diller said today the countdown, which began Sunday night, was proceeding without trouble. ``Everything is great - not a hitch,'' he said. But Air Force meteorologists today were forecasting only a 30 percent chance of good weather at launch time - down 10 percent from Monday's predictions. The main concern is cross winds at the launch site, Diller said. Better weather conditions were expected on Friday and Saturday. The mission originally was scheduled for July but was delayed, like shuttle Columbia's flight, by dangerous hydrogen leaks. The shuttles were pronounced safe to fly after fueling tests last month.

DOC.HEAD: Government Probe Finds No Evidence of Police Death Squads
DOC.NOTE: Eds: First 20 grafs EMBARGOED for 10:45 a.m. EST; time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: A Supreme Court justice appointed to investigate unsolved killings of anti-apartheid activists said today he found no evidence the police or army operated death squads. Government opponents who have long blamed the security forces for the deaths of dozens of activists were certain to protest the finding. In another development, police said today that seven blacks were shot and stabbed to death in the troubled black townships outside Johannesburg. An eighth death was reported in Wenbezi, northwest of Durban. The finding on the death squads came from Supreme Court Justice Louis Harms, the sole member of a government-appointed commission. He described as unreliable three former policemen who said they carried out more than 10 killings as part of authorized death squads. Harms said killings described by the former policemen ``undoubtedly took place,'' but that ``it would be very difficult in the extreme to prove the veracity of the allegations in criminal proceedings.'' Police and the military have denied the existence of death squads. They said any criminal acts carried out against the anti-apartheid camp were undertaken by individuals acting on their own. Harms said there was a probability that police committed violent crimes against members of black opposition groups such as the African National Congress, which was legalized in February after being outlawed for 30 years. But he added there was no evidence that ``a particular policeman committed a particular crime of violence for a particular purpose.'' Another government commission that investigated the allegations last year and released its findings Saturday reached the same conclusion. Harms also said a covert military group, the Civil Cooperation Bureau, had ``contaminated'' the whole security arm of the state and there was reason to suspect it was involved ``in more crimes of violence than the evidence shows.'' Among the few operations the bureau admitted carrying out was hanging a baboon fetus on the door of a home belonging to Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu. Harms heard testimony from dozens of witnesses from March through August as he examined more than 60 unsolved killings of anti-apartheid activists. He said two 1986 slayings should be investigated further by prosecutors but did not make such a recommendation in any of the other killings. Former policeman Almond Nofomela caused the inquiries into the alleged death squads Oct. 19, 1989, the day before he was scheduled to be executed for a killing with no apparent political overtones. Nofomela said he and two former colleagues took part in many killings and kidnappings authorized by superiors. The other two fled the country, then said they had joined in the killings described by Nofomela, who remains on death row.
DOC.HEAD: END MATERIAL EMBARGOED for 10:45 a.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: In the township violence, the worst fighting was in Katlehong, southeast of Johannesburg, where police discovered five bodies this morning with bullet and knife wounds. A police spokeswoman, Lt. Ida van Zweel, said the battles were between rival Zulu and Xhosa residents of a squatter camp, who have been fighting since Sunday. She said the bloodshed began after one group demanded the other take part in a rent boycott. Authorities also found a body in Evaton and another in Vosloorus, both south of Johannesburg. Meanwhile, police denied that they deliberately targeted Winnie Mandela, wife of ANC leader Nelson Mandela, when they fired tear gas on blacks in Atteridgeville township outside Pretoria on Monday. A police spokesman, Maj. Reg Crewe, said tear gas was used to disperse a stone-throwing crowd in the township, where police and residents have clashed several times in recent days. Mrs. Mandela, who was visiting residents to show support, said: ``It is clear the attack was deliberately directed at me and my delegation.'' In another development, a white extremist testified he stabbed and shot to death a black taxi driver because he needed practice before embarking on a campaign to assassinate black leaders. ``It would be fatal to get cold feet if I had a leader in my sights,'' Cornelius Lottering said Monday in the Johannesburg Supreme Court, where he is on trial for murder. He has pleaded innocent, saying the killing was an act of war. White extremists upset by President F.W. de Klerk's political reforms have vowed to fight rather than accept a black majority government in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Militias Complete Withdrawal From Beirut
DOC.TEXT: The three main Moslem and leftist militias announced today they have completed their withdrawal from Beirut ahead of a government deadline to remove the forces from the capital. In the Christian heartland, the Lebanese army began closing down militia centers estabished by Syrian-backed groups, a condition set by the main Christian militia for pulling out of Beirut. President Elias Hrawi, seeking to re-establish central authority and end Lebanon's 15{-year-old civil war, has ordered all militias out of the Beirut area by Nov. 19. The militias are responsible for most of the 150,000 deaths in the civil war. The pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, said it has withdrawn its fighters and weapons from the southern slums of the capital, where Moslem militants once held most of the 13 Westerners missing in Lebanon. Hezbollah's rival Shiite Moslem group, Amal, and the leftist Druse Progressive Socialist Party made similar announcements. ``We have completed implementation of the part concerning us of the greater Beirut plan,'' said a Hezbollah spokesman, who asked not to be named. Beirut newspapers have reported that the hostages were moved out of the capital to east Lebanon in early October, when it became apparent that Hrawi's government was serious in ridding Beirut of the militias. The 13 hostages include six Americans. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped on March 16, 1985. Most of the hostages are held by underground factions linked to Hezbollah, although the group denies any involvement. Druse warlord Walid Jumblatt's Progressive Socialist Party said in a statement that it has pulled out of the southeastern suburbs to the Chouf mountains southeast of the capital, while Nabih Berri's Amal withdrew to south and east Lebanon. The government said its army would begin house-to-house searches on Nov. 20 to make sure there are no militia elements remain in the capital area. Hrawi's government took control after a Syrian-led assault on Oct. 13 crushed an 11-month rebellion by Gen. Michel Aoun. Aoun had opposed an Arab League plan to end the civil war, saying there was no guarantee that Syria, which had 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League mandate, would leave. The peace pact includes political reforms that redistribute power equally between Christians and Moslems. Aoun and Hrawi are Christians. Christians had maintained the upper hand in government since independence from France in 1943.

DOC.HEAD: President Must Explain Need for Persian Gulf War: Analysts
DOC.NOTE: EDs: TOPS with 4 grafs to update with Lugar and Kerrey calling for congressional debate; SUBS last two graphs, to DELETE reference to 70 percent of world's oil which questionable
DOC.TEXT: Demands that President Bush do a better job convincing the American people of the need for a Persian Gulf war escalated today when the Republican former chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee urged the president to clarify U.S. aims in the region. ``I think the president must lay out now to the nation and the Congress specifically what our aims are,'' said Sen. Richard Lugar of Indiana. In an appearance on NBC's ``Today'' show, Lugar also urged Bush to call a special session of Congress to debate the issues involved in the U.S. confrontation with Iraq ``and vote - affirmatively I would prsume - so that we have authorization for what is required.'' Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., who has criticized the administration's policy in the Persian Gulf, said on ABC's ``Good Morning America'' that ``as representatives of the people we should be engaged in the debate about the purpose of this involvement and perhaps some suggested alternatives.'' ``I don't think we've done a very good job in the administration of explaining to the American people in depth what this is all about,'' said Lance Tarrance, a Republican pollster based in Texas. ``We learned from Vietnam that Americans have to be convinced and sold on a rationale for our involvement,'' said Neil Newhouse, a pollster with the Republican firm headed by Richard Wirthlin. War worries swept Washington the past week after Bush announced a substantial increase in the U.S. military presence in the Persian Gulf. The announcement also triggered speculation on the impact that hostilities would have on the 1992 presidential election. Public support for Bush's handling of the gulf crisis has fallen from 82 percent in late August to 51 percent this week, according to a poll published today by ``USA Today.'' The telphone poll Monday of 615 adults also showed that only 51 percent approved of Bush's decision last week to send 200,000 more U.S. troops to the region, while 38 percent said they disapproved, the newspaper said. The poll, by Gordon S. Black, had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percent, meaning that if every adult in the country were surveyed, the results would not differ more than 4 percentage points either way. During the final days of this year's campaign, Bush stepped up his attacks on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and was widely credited by politicians with shifting the focus of the debate from domestic issues that were hurting Republican candidates. Would a war guarantee Bush's re-election? Most analysts said hostilities contained more political dangers than benefits for him. ``Don't overestimate the patience of the American people and don't underestimate the expectations,'' said Newhouse. He added that most Americans expect a war with Iraq would be won as quickly as the actions against Grenada and Panama, which ended within days. ``I think that's going to be the wild card in this next presidential election,'' said John White, a former Democratic Party chairman. ``If we have a war, if there are high casualties, it will be a referendum on George Bush.'' White predicted that in the event of war, the Democrats would have to nominate for president in 1992 ``someone who warned or tried to prevent this thing from happening.'' Democrats who fit that description are beginning to emerge, among them Sen. Sam Nunn of Georgia, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. Nunn said Sunday that ``the last thing we need is to have a war over there, a bloody war, and have American boys being sent and brought back in body bags and yet not have the American people behind them.'' Nunn frequently is mentioned as a likely contender for the 1992 Democratic presidential nomination. ``We can say here's what we think will happen, or here's how the American people will react,'' said Democratic pollster Peter Hart. ``Nobody can know. You don't know how you would react; I don't know how I would react.'' The one area on which all analysts agreed was the need for the president to explain more compellingly the need for Americans to fight and die in the Middle East. Conservative David Keene said the impact of a war on the 1992 elections would ``depend on how the war goes and how well the president is able to articulate his reasons for taking that step. I think the public will support a winning military effort if it isn't too costly or too long if they understand the reasons for it. ``The problem at this point is that we've gotten ourselves bogged down over there for a long period of time with the president issuing conflicting reasons and rationales for our being there,'' Keene said. Sometimes it's to deter aggression; sometimes it's energy; sometimes it's democratic values.'' Tarrance said, ``The politics are too complex and Americans are too used to these complexities to buy simple naked aggression as the only cause.'' The Texas pollster suggested that Bush must explain that Iraqi control of a substantial portion of the world's oil would ``bring Western civilization to its knees ... and somebody better start describing what that means.'' ``People look toward the president today as an explainer of events,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Musical About Relationships Opens off-Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned.
DOC.TEXT: In ``Catch Me if I Fall,'' which has book, music and lyrics by Barbara Schottenfeld, the title song explains what the five main characters want in a loved one. But only Laura Dean, as a young woman from Romania, continually breaks through the brittle surface of this musical about New York relationships to give the cynical, hip, amusing, deliberately shallow show warmth, emotional feeling and depth. ``Catch Me if I Fall'' opened Monday night at off-Broadway's Promenade Theater. The plot ostensibly centers around Lonny, turning 40, who quit sculpting to work for a corporate headhunter. James Judy, as Lonny, doesn't look like a ladies' man but he and ex-wife Laurie (Jeanine Morick) still have a yen for each other. He lives with Godiva (Ronnie Farer), a veterinarian who concentrates more on her career than on him. And he marries - in name only - Domnica (Laura Dean), the Romanian girlfriend of his boss, Peter (Sal Viviano), because her visitors' permit is about to expire and Peter's divorce isn't final. One of the musical's high points is Peter's crass and loving song, ``The Beach House,'' which he's determined not to give up in the divorce settlement. But the focus of the musical is really on Domnica. Everybody else's problems are the stuff of musical comedy. The ex-wife, told her neurotic self is talking, cracks, ``My neurotic self is the real me.'' Her small son (David Burdick) has a smart mouth. The vet's beeper calls her, in the middle of a kiss, to a pregnant poodle. Schottenfeld's lyrics are literate and clever. Musically, she has been listening to Stephen Sondheim ballads. Her best melodies are ``Home Never Leaves You'' and ``Isn't It Strange (That We Can Love Again).'' Susan Einhorn directed. G.W. Mercier designed costumes and sets, some inside slide-away cylindrical walls for quick changes. The Never or Now Company produced in association with Frederick Schultz and Terry A. Johnston. Schottenfeld currently is writing lyrics for Jule Styne's upcoming Broadway musical, ``The Red Shoes.''

DOC.HEAD: Radical Lawmaker Says British Hostages to Be Freed Soon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with reaction from British government, friends of hostages, background on Iran-Britain ties. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: A leading radical lawmaker in Iran was quoted today as saying British hostages held in Lebanon will be freed within a few days. Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, a former interior minister who reportedly has close links to fundamentalists in Lebanon, said the releases will come over his objections. He acknowledged that pro-Iranian militants holding the hostages were under increasing pressure by unspecified Lebanese Moslem groups. ``I can only express my regret,'' the parliamentarian told the Iranian newspaper Abrar in response to a question about the four British hostages. ``We see that the British hostges are due to be released within the next few days due to the pressures on Lebanese Moslem groups.'' Friends and relatives of the British hostages reacted cautiously. ``It looks like a very good piece of news, but unfortunately we have heard many comments like it before, though not, as far as I know, from Mr. Mohtashemi,'' said Catherine Comerford, a member of a support group for hostage John McCarthy. ``My reaction is understandably cautious after all that we have heard before,'' said David Waite, brother of Anglican envoy Terry Waite, who disappeared in Beirut in 1987. The other British hostages are writer Alec Collett and former pilot Jack Mann. The British Foreign Office said it did not have any information to substantiate the Mohtashemi report. Knowledgeable sources in the Middle East who follow the hostage issue closely said there was nothing to indicate a hostage release was imminent. The sources, insisting that they not be identified further, said Mohtashemi's remarks may be aimed at increasing pressure on Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani to seek word on Iranians missing in Lebanon. Mohtashemi did not further specify where the pressures to free the four Britons were coming from. But in the course of the interview, he complained about a Syrian-backed plan to pacify Lebanon and disband militias there. Pressures to free the hostages could also be coming from Mohtashemi's Iranian rivals, led by Rafsanjani, who reportedly are seeking to end the ordeal of hostages in Lebanon to improve his country's relations with the West. Mohtashemi did not comment on the fate of the nine other Western captives in Lebanon, including six Americans. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985 in Beirut. Mohtashemi said five Iranians have been held by Christian militiamen in Lebanon since 1982. It was the first time that an Iranian official has spoken of five Iranians. Earlier, Rafsanjani's government had offered to help free Western captives in return for information about four Iranians who were kidnapped in 1982 by Christian militiamen in north Lebanon. Mohtashemi identified the fifth as an Alim, or a Moslem scholar. He only provided his second name as Tavassoli and said he disappeared during Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon. Lebanese sources say the Iranians are dead. But Iranian officials have said in the past that they have information four are alive. Most of the Western captives in Lebanon are believed held by pro-Iranian extremists, operating under the Hezbollah Shiite Moslem group. There had been speculation at least one British hostage would be freed after the resumption of London-Tehran relations last month. But these hopes dimmed after a Syrian government newspaper, Tishrin, wrote that no hostage will be freed from Lebanon until London restores ties with Damascus. Their relations were broken in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Fraternity Rape Still A Mystery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to raise reference to 18-year-old accuser and CORRECT that Lindell shot self at house he shared, not at parents' house. Picks up 5th graf, `Hours earlier....'.
DOC.TEXT: Right after the fraternity party the young woman could remember it all so clearly: A pledge had raped her as several others watched, she told police. A week and a half later her memory failed. But by then, one youth who had been at the party was dying, an apparent suicide, and another had been held without bail for a week in prison, accused of a rape he denies committing. The 18-year-old woman who accused the student now says she was drunk and testified in court that she no longer remembers everything that happened. She has not been identified by the media because of the nature of the case. ``It's just a big mess,'' said Sandra Wall, 21, who writes for the University of Rhode Island newspaper. ``I want to hold somebody responsible but it's a tragedy. ... There really is no answer and there is nobody to blame.'' Michael Lindell, 20, never a suspect in the alleged rape Oct. 27 at the Tau Kappa Epsilon house at the University of Rhode Island, died Wednesday at a hospital after shooting himself in the head at the house he shared with John J. Birchall, who owned the house. Hours earlier, Dave Lallemand, 19, who was charged with the rape but maintained his innocence, was freed when his accuser said she had forgotten the details. Pawtucket police Monday disclosed that a note was found at Lindell's home. ``It was a very vague note and I would not necessarily term it a suicide note,'' said detective Lt. Thomas Harris. He wouldn't elaborate. Harris said Lindell, a former URI student who knew members of the fraternity, knew state police wanted to question him about what he saw at the party. Investigators haven't said whether they were linking his death to the alleged rape. State Police Lt. Brian Andrews said detectives have concluded their investigation and will present the evidence to a grand jury. Neither Lallemand nor his accuser could be reached for comment Monday. There was no answer at the woman's dorm room. Lallemand was not at his parents' home in Westford, Mass., where he abruptly returned on Sunday. ``No one knows what he's going through,'' said Michael P. Brady, 21, Tau Kappa Epsilon president. ``We really don't know what happened,'' said Brady, of Albany, N.Y. ``We're not saying nothing happened. ... We can't really fit things together.'' The woman, an 18-year-old freshman, told police she was raped in an upstairs bedroom at TKE in South Kingston by a man she met that evening. Police interviewed her three times within hours of the incident. She said her attacker wore a TKE pledge pin and immediately identified the 6-foot-7 Lallemand when shown pictures of the 21 fraternity pledges, police said. Lallemand was charged and held at the state prison for a week until a bail hearing Wednesday. It was then the woman testified she had been ``very drunk'' at the party and could no longer recall everything that had happened. ``Dave began touching me and, you know, I was telling him, `I'm not that kind of girl,''' she testified. ``From then on I'm blank.'' The next thing she remembers, she said, was standing up from a sofa with her pants and underwear at her knees and seeing Lallemand and four other men. Two or three men ``were trying to pull my pants back down'' she said. ``They were just laughing.'' She said she couldn't recall other things she had told police. The judge refused to admit her statements to police as evidence and dismissed the case. The university suspended activities at the fraternity after the incident. Brady said one of TKE's 85 members had his car vandalized and the word ``rapist'' scrawled in lipstick on his windshield. ``We're taking kind of a beating,'' he said. ``If the same thing happened in a dorm it wouldn't even get in the press.'' The 10,000-student university suspended two fraternities in 1988, one for hazing and one for possession of stolen goods. ``We've made so many changes and become so strict. ... I'm surprised anything happened,'' said Lloyd Sprague, president of a student board that oversees the university's 14 fraternities. ``It's definitely put us back a few years.''

DOC.HEAD: `Child's Play' No. 1 at the Box Office

DOC.HEAD: Former U.S. Attorney General Says Four American Hostages To Be Freed
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraq will release four more American hostages, former U.S. Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today after concluding an independent peace mission to Baghdad. ``I was told that two were going to be released today and apparently did not make it on the plane and that they will be out on the next plane whenever that is,'' Clark told reporters on arrival in Amman from Baghdad. ``I think it will be tomorrow and there will be two more after that,'' said Clark, who arrived on the daily Iraqi Airways flight from the Iraqi capital. Clark, a peace activist who traveled to Hanoi during the Vietnam War, is the second prominent American to go to Baghdad since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Former presidential candidate Jesse Jackson was there in August. During his three-day visit Clark criticized the United States for not seeking a negotiated settlement to the Persian Gulf crisis and chastised Iraq for holding foreign hostages as a ``human shield'' against air raids by the predominantly U.S. forces deployed in Saudi Arabia. The official Iraqi News Agency reported that Clark had conferred with top Iraqi officials, including President Saddam Hussein. Clark said he met with American hostages who have taken refuge at the U.S. ambassador's residence in Baghdad. ``They want to go home. They want liberty, they want to be free. But their physical and mental health seem excellent as far as I could tell,'' he said. There were 3,500 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait before the invasion. Some 600 remain in hiding or are held in Kuwait. About 330 are detained in Iraq, including 104 men held at 30 strategic sites throughout the country. Many Western leaders have said independent missions to Baghdad by former leaders could be used to split the alliance against Iraq. Clark was attorney general under President Johnson from 1966 to 1969.

DOC.HEAD: Former Aide to Georgia Governor Fails to Kill Libel Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Tom Perdue, onetime top aide to Georgia Gov. Joe Frank Harris, failed today in a Supreme Court attempt to kill a libel lawsuit against him by state Public Service Commission member J. Mac Barber. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that Barber's allegations that Perdue falsely accused him of bribery should go to a jury. The commission was the target of a bribery investigation in 1984 and 1985. Barber was never charged with a crime as a result of that investigation, but others were indicted. Barber resigned from the commission in 1985 but qualified to run in 1986 for the seat he had left 18 months previously. In that 1986 election, Barber lost to Gary Andrews, the man appointed to succeed him. Barber regained a commission seat in elections this month. During the 1986 campaign, Perdue sent a letter to about 350 city and county officials throughout the state urging them to oppose Barber's election. In the letter, Perdue said, ``A Public Service Commissioner betrayed the public trust ... by accepting what amounted to a bribe.'' The letter added: ``When confronted with the fact that the attorney general and the Georgia Bureau of Investigation had this information and were about to seek a felony indictment, Mac Barber chose to resign his office rather than face the prospect of indictment and conviction. The trucking company official who gave Mac Barber the money was convicted and fined a total of $12,000.'' A state trial judge threw out Barber's suit, ruling that there was no ``actual malice'' - knowledge or reckless disregard of falsity. But the Georgia Court of Appeals reinstated the suit by a 5-4 vote last year. ``There is undisputed evidence that (Perdue) knew that (Barber) had not been convicted or even indicted for bribery, yet stated that he was guilty of it,'' the state court said. ``A jury can reasonably infer that he stated his opinion as though it were an official fact, despite the accusation's not having been proved beyond a reasonable doubt in a court of law.'' The Georgia Supreme Court refused, 4-2, to hear Perdue's ensuing appeal. In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for Perdue said the case is not one that should reach a jury. They said Perdue had sat in on a meeting between the governor and Barber before the 1985 resignation, had reviewed the GBI file on the commission bribery investigation, discussed his letter with the attorney general and received approval by a lawyer on the governor's staff. In urging the justices to reject Perdue's appeal, lawyers for Barber said the former governor's aide ``uttered false statements of fact which Perdue knew to be false, or whose falsity Perdue recklessly disregarded.'' The case is Perdue vs. Barber, 90-502.

DOC.HEAD: Killer Revealed But ``Twin Peaks'' Second
DOC.TEXT: Although ``Twin Peaks'' finally appeared to reveal the killer of Laura Palmer, the show only came in second in ratings in its time period, despite heavy advance publicity, Nielsen estimates showed today. But that was the show's highest rating so far this season. Saturday's episode, in which Palmer's father appeared to be displaying a second personality as the killer, averaged a 10.4 rating. While up considerably from its 7.8 ratings average for the three previous weeks, Saturday's episode of ``Peaks'' couldn't beat NBC's opposing ``Carol & Company'' and ``American Dreamer.'' NBC won the hour with an 11.8 ratings average, with Carol Burnett's anthology comedy show getting a 13.8 and ``Dreamer'' a 9.8. But ``Peaks'' beat CBS' ``Wiseguy'' season premiere, third with a 6.8 average. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes. ABC had refused to give TV critics advance tapes of the show for screening, a policy it has had since ``Peaks'' premiered last season.

DOC.HEAD: Court Turns Away Wisconsin Controversy Over Association Spending
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today turned away a Wisconsin controversy over how much money associations may spend in communicating with their members about political matters. The justices, without comment, left intact rulings that the dispute is not yet ready for intervention by the courts. The Wisconsin Education Association Council (WEAC), a voluntary organization of teachers and other public school employees, had urged the court to rule that a state law limiting campaign spending cannot be applied to an association's messages to its members. The appeal acted on today said applying the campaign-spending limits to such communications would violate free-speech and associational rights. WEAC announced in the spring of 1988 that it intended to hire about 20 of its members to work toward mobilizing the association's membership in support of those candidates whom WEAC planned to endorse in the November elections. After learning of WEAC's intention, members of the State Elections Board expressed concern that certain activities, if undertaken at the request or suggestion of a candidate, might constitute contributions to that candidate. Wisconsin law imposes limits on individual campaign contributions of $1,000 per state Senate race and $500 per state assembly race. The elections board met with WEAC's legislative director in July 1988, and in August sent the association a letter stating the board planned no formal action because there was no evidence that WEAC had violated any campaign law. WEAC sued the elections board in state court that September, seeking a ruling that any expenses incurred in political communications with its members were exempt from the spending limits - even those incurred as a result of contact with an endorsed candidate or that candidate's campaign committee. State courts, including the Wisconsin Supreme Court last June, refused to rule on WEAC's constitutional claims. The state courts said the claim was premature because the elections board had taken no action. ``To resolve WEAC's constitutional claims would require the court to speculate both on the nature of WEAC's conduct and on the enforcement posture of the board with respect to that conduct,'' the state court said. In a dissenting opinion from the June ruling, Justice William Bablitch said such associational expenditures ``need not be reported and are not contributions within the meaning'' of the Wisconsin law. Bablitch chastised his court for leaving WEAC leaders ``in an untenable position'' in which they ``could forego political activity which they believe is constitutionally protected or ... proceed with their plans at their peril.'' The case is Wisconsin Education Association Council vs. Wisconsin State Elections Board, 90-492.

DOC.HEAD: Leningrad Considers Expanded Rationing
DOC.TEXT: Leningrad's reformist mayor urged the City Council today to ration eggs, flour, meat and other necessities, saying it is the only way the city will get through the winter without hunger and unrest. ``The entire country is introducing ration cards, and we unfortunately cannot avoid it either,'' Mayor Anatoly Sobchak said. Soviet television showed shoppers in Leningrad, the country's second-largst city, waiting in 500-yard-long lines for ordinary items like butter, milk and chocolate. ``Citizens standing in queues since morning want their representatives to take faster, and most of all, more decisive actions,'' the television announcer said. A few items are already rationed in Leningrad, but the new plan, if adopted, would be one of the most comprehensive rationing plans in the country. Leningrad officials said the council was likely to make a decision Thursday. Sobchak suggested that without rationing, public anger over shortages could endanger President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's political reforms. ``Democracy is facing a hungry winter,'' he said. ``It is crucial for democracy to survive this winter. The only solution I see is to introduce ration cards now.'' Moscow already has rationed sugar and cigarettes, limiting residents to 4.4 pounds of sugar and 10 packs of cigarettes per person in November. Moscow's City Council is expected to expand its ration system to include meat, butter and flour starting Dec. 1. Soviet newspapers have given varying accounts of the amounts of those items that Moscow residents would be allowed to buy. Local officials in other cities have rationed meat, vodka, butter and similar staples. In some regions, particularly in northern Russia where supplies grow scarce in winter, limited rationing has been in effect for years. But it is becoming more and more widespread. In Leningrad, the city's 4.8 million residents already receive monthly ration coupons for 4.4 pounds of sugar, one bottle of vodka and two bottles of wine. A commission headed by Marina Salye, a prominent reformist politician, has recommended new limits of 2.6 pounds of meat, 1.1 pounds of chicken, and 2.2 pounds of sausage. In addition, each resident would be allotted 10 eggs, 1.1 pounds of butter, 2.2 pounds of cereal or pasta, 1.1 pounds of flour and two-thirds of a pound of vegetable oil. Leningrad residents also would receive monthly coupons for five packs of cigarettes. The threat of widespread hunger is a particularly sensitive issue in Leningrad, where many still remember the Nazi siege of September 1941 to January 1944, when thousands died of starvation. Leonid Dobrovolsky, deputy chairman of the Leningrad Food Supply Commission, opposed the rationing proposal. He told the council that state-owned plants might not be able to supply even the limited amounts of food the council had in mind. ``In 1991, none of the food factories in Leningrad will be able to guarantee the manufacture of foodstuffs or make plans, because their suppliers are not meeting their obligations and have not signed new contracts,'' he was quoted as saying by Maxim Korzhavin, a free-lance Soviet journalist who spoke to The Associated Press by telephone from Leningrad. An alternative proposal would raise prices on basic foodstuffs to give suppliers an incentive to send food to the city. Poor families would receive state subsidies or food coupons to make up for the higher prices. But Korzhavin said the majority of the city council members appeared to favor the expanded rationing.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Legislator Fails In Attempt to Avoid Libel Suit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 5, At the time, to say Anthony Celebrezze was candidate for governor.
DOC.TEXT: An Ohio legislator who used the term ``Mafia'' in opposing the re-election of an Italian member of the state's highest court failed today in a Supreme Court bid to avoid a libel lawsuit. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that Robert E. Netzley, a Republican member of the Ohio House of Representatives from Miami County, must defend himself against James P. Celebrezze's lawsuit. Today's action clears the way for a trial. Celebrezze, a Democrat, was an associate justice of the Ohio Supreme Court from January 1983 through December 1984. He was defeated in a 1984 election against Craig W. Wright, a Republican. At the time, Celebrezze's brother, Frank D. Celebrezze, was chief justice of the Ohio Supreme Court. His cousin, Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr., was the state's attorney general. Anthony Celebrezze was the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for governor in this month's election. Netzley, who was chairman of the Miami County Republican Committee, prepared the campaign pamphlet Celebrezze sued over. The pamphlet, generally endorsing Republican candidates for various offices, urged voters to ``Judge the Court.'' The pamphlet stated: ``It's no wonder that some are calling Ohio's Justice System the `Mafia Family' Court. Take a look. Frank Celebrezze, Chief Justice, Brother Jimmy Celebrezze, Associate Justice, Cousin Tony Celebrezze, Ohio Attorney General, and Frank Celebrezze's `Crony' Angelo Gagliardi, intimidator in charge of the Ohio Disciplinary Council.'' In his lawsuit, Celebrezze contends that no other person had ever referred to the Ohio Supreme Court members as a Mafia family and that Netzley knew none of those mentioned in the pamphlet was in any way connected with the Mafia or organized crime. Celebrezze's suit also named as defendants the Miami County Republican Committee and The Plain Dealer in Cleveland, which published an article about the pamphlet. A state trial judge ordered the Plain Dealer dropped as a defendant but rejected requests by Netzley and the GOP committee to have the suit against them dismissed. A state appeals court, ruling that the pamphlet was an expression of opinion, threw out the suit. But the Ohio Supreme Court, its ranks bolstered by substitute judges who had no conflict of interest in the case, voted 5-2 last May to reinstate it. The state court said the judge's denial of the dismissal requests could not be appealed until after a trial was conducted. Netzley, but not the county GOP committee, then sought help from the nation's highest court. The case is Netzley vs. Celebrezze, 90-480.

DOC.HEAD: Man Killed in Gunfight With Undercover Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: A man was shot and killed today in a gunfight with undercover soldiers in Northern Ireland, news reports said. The Royal Ulster Constabulary said the man was killed in the village of Victoria Bridge, 90 miles west of Belfast, when the home of a member of the security forces came under gunfire. ``The army returned fire. One man was killed and a machine gun was found in a car,'' the constabulary said in a statement. It said there were no security force casualties, and that ``a number'' of people were arrested. Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, said two more arrests were made after dogs tracked the men to fields close to the scene. Undercover soldiers were guarding the home of the Ulster Defense Regiment member when the gunmen attacked, the news agency said. Quoting unidentified sources, the news agency reported that the dead man was Alex Patterson, a suspected terrorist with links to the Irish National Liberation Army. The Irish National Liberation Army is an illegal paramilitary group fighting for British withdrawal from Northern Ireland. Patterson was the ninth person to be killed by the security forces in Northern Ireland this year. On Jan. 13, three robbery suspects were shot to death by army undercover officers in west Belfast. The victims were later determined to be petty criminals armed with fake guns. One man was killed by the army in an ambush April 18 near the home of a police reserve officer. The victim was later identified as a member of the Irish Peoples' Liberation Army, an anti-British splinter group. On Sept. 31, two teen-age joyriders who drove a stolen car through a security checkpoint were shot to death in Belfast. Soldiers shot and killed an IRA member and member of the IRA's political wing, Sinn Fein, on Oct. 9.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Ruling on Administration of Mind-Altering Drugs Set Aside
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today set aside a ruling that let Louisiana officials give mind-altering drugs to a convicted mass murderer in the hope he could be made sane enough to execute. The justices ordered a state court to restudy its ruling in the case of death row inmate Michael Owen Perry. Today's one-paragraph, unsigned opinion directed the Louisiana court to reconsider Perry's case in light of a Supreme Court decision in February permitting prison officials to force inmates to take powerful anti-psychotic drugs without a judge's consent. The February ruling gave officials broad power to administer the drugs to maintain order in the prisons - but only if prison doctors determined the medication is in the inmate's medical interest. It was not immediately clear what effect today's ruling will have on Perry's case. He was convicted of killing his parents and three other relatives in their Lake Arthur, La., home in 1983. Perry was judged to be sane when he committed the crimes and mentally competent to stand trial. Officials said he became psychotic while on death row. A 1986 Supreme Court ruling bars states from executing anyone who is insane. Psychiatrists have testified that when Perry is taking anti-psychotic drugs he is competent to be executed - meaning he realizes he is going to be executed because he killed five people. The medical director at Angola Prison in Louisiana testified that Perry told him, ``It's very simple. Take my pills and die. Don't take my pills and live.'' There were no recorded dissents from today's ruling. Justice David H. Souter did not take part in the case. The case is Perry vs. Louisiana, 89-5120.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Reportedly Hiding in Kuwait Call TV Station
With PM-Gulf-Ex-Hostages
DOC.TEXT: A man who said he was among a group of Americans hiding in Kuwait urged U.S. military action against Iraq during a telephone call to a television station. ``We feel that our protectors have hidden us away well enough and safe enough so that if they start bombing, we feel very good, 95 percent sure, we can come through the war and get back home,'' the caller said. WJW-TV received the unsolicited call Monday and confirmed it came from Kuwait, producer Tom Reed said. Newsman John O'Day spoke with men from Ohio and Maryland. The station did not identify them. The Ohio caller said the group has gone from place to place to avoid detection. About 2,000 Westerners are believed to be in hiding in Kuwait in addition to the more than 400 being held by Iraq as so-called human shields, according to U.S. State Department figures. The caller said the consensus among the group is that military force should be applied as soon as possible. ``If they use the military option I really feel that in three or four days I could be out of Kuwait and ... on a plane back to see my family,'' he said. The caller said the group hangs on every bit of news from the United States. ``We go from a very high high to very low lows,'' he said. ``To give an example, last week when we heard the president was willing to wait until February to see if sanctions could work ... we went from a group of happy guys to two of us crying.''

DOC.HEAD: British Pilot Killed in Gulf Crash
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A British fighter plane on a training mission in the Persian Gulf crashed today and the pilot was killed, the Defense Ministry said. The Jaguar aircraft, based in Bahrain, crashed in the desert in the gulf nation of Qatar, a Royal Air Force spokesman in London said. A board of inquiry was being convened to determine the cause of the crash, the ministry said. The pilot was identified as Lt. Keith Collister, 26, from 54 Squadron of the Royal Air Force. It was the first crash of a Jaguar, sent to the gulf with the initial British deployment following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The spokesman said the pilot was the first RAF member to die in an accident in the gulf. The pilot was the only person aboard the jet.

DOC.HEAD: Two Dead, Two Hurt in New Zealand Village Shootings
DOC.TEXT: A man armed with a high-powered rifle terrorized a small township today, killing a 5-year-old boy and a 62-year-old man and wounding two children, police said. A policeman was also missing. Police assisted with a helicopter were scouring steep hillsides and sandy, open marshland looking for the gunman, believed to be in his late 20s and a resident of the Aramoana township. Hospital officials said the two injured children were in stable condition after undergoing surgery. Senior Sgt. Bill O'Brien said of the missing policeman: ``We hold grave fears for his safety.'' The township, with a population of only around 50, is nearly 20 miles north of Dunedin on the east coast of New Zealand's South Island. O'Brien said the 4-year-old boy and the 9-year-old girl had undergone surgery for gunshot wounds. The 62-year-old man had been admitted to hospital in intensive care but later died, police said. The names of the dead or injured were not immediately released. Some residents were trapped in their homes for hours, and others were spending the night in a nearby town hall. Details about the shooting were sketchy. Residents said the trouble began when a house caught fire. New Zealand Press Association quoted resident Dorothy Crimp as saying she saw the blaze and then heard gunshots ``from all around the area.'' A young woman came to her home screaming that her children were in the burning house, then disappeared, Mrs. Crimp said. The agency said another resident reported he went to try to help put the fire out, but a woman ran toward him screaming that a neighbor had ``gone crazy'' with a gun. Seconds later, the man and several friends were shot at, he said. The group ran to a nearby mini-van and drove away, with the driver ducking more shots.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Stock Exchange Founded, But No Big Board Yet
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has created a Moscow Stock Exchange, the first in the country since the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution. The official Tass news agency said the exchange was founded Monday by 187 Soviet enterprises and banks. It did not say when trading would begin. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev issued an order Oct. 26 permitting Soviet citizens to buy stocks, bonds and other securities as part of his plan to switch from central planning to a market economy. Tass said the Moscow Stock Exchange would be represented overseas by an international brokerage company that has asked not to be identified. The exchange plans to open offices in the world's major stock exchanges in New York, Frankfurt, Tokyo and Singapore, the news agency said. Trading in shares was outlawed following the Bolshevik Revolution. A flourishing stock market in St. Petersburg, now Leningrad, was closed along with more than 100 commodity exchanges elsewhere in Russia. The New York Stock Exchange recently gave a three-day seminar in Moscow on how to revive, operate and regulate financial markets. NYSE Chairman John Phelan and his Soviet hosts agreed that limited trading could begin within a year. Soviet businessman Eduard Tenyakov, one of the main organizers of a Moscow stock exchange, said the ruble would be valued on a par with the U.S. dollar in estimating the currency exchange values of shares. The ruble is not a convertible currency, and exchange rates are set artifically by the government. A new commercial exchange rate was imposed on Nov. 1, cutting the value of the Soviet currency by nearly 70 percent to discourage imports. The new rate for international commercial transactions is 1.8 rubles per U.S. dollar, compared to the old .56 rubles to the dollar. The rate for foreign tourists exchanging money in the Soviet Union remained unchanged at six rubles to the dollar.

DOC.HEAD: CNN Reports Iraq Diverted USDA Loans to Buy Trucks, Hardware
DOC.TEXT: Iraq may have used U.S.-backed loans to obtain trucks and other equipment for its invasion of Kuwait, and kickbacks on its subsidized purchases of U.S. food to buy weapons, according to a report. Cable News Network reported Monday that Iraq diverted millions of dollars from loans backed by the U.S. Department of Agriculture - intended to help Iraq buy surplus food from U.S. farmers - to obtain trucks and other hardware used in the invasion. ``Unfortunately, the U.S. soldier in Operation Desert Shield faces an Iraqi army that probably has been fed with USDA-guaranteed loans on food and has been transported around the country of Iraq on transportation equipment that was provided as bribes for companies to do business with Iraq,'' Rep. Charles Rose, D-N.C., told CNN. ``And that should send a cold shiver up and down the back of every American,'' he added. Iraq has borrowed $5 billion in USDA-backed loans since 1983, when President Reagan started the program to aid the Iraqis in their war with Iran and to help U.S. farmers sell surplus commodities. Iraq still owes $2 billion on the loans, but stopped making payments when it invaded Kuwait this summer. Although Iraq was supposed to buy only food and other agriculture products with the loans, Iraqi officials demanded the American exporters give them trucks, trailers, cranes, spare parts and other industrial equipment as part of their purchases, CNN said, citing federal investigation reports. Investigators also believe Iraq used the U.S.-backed loans to buy weapons by overpaying American companies for food and then demanding that they transfer cash kickbacks to bank accounts in Europe, CNN said. CNN said several unidentified agricultural companies confirmed that they wired money to European banks for Iraq, but said Iraqi officials told them the money would be used to buy agriculture items, not weapons. Rose told the network: ``Federal investigators have told me that they have found instances in which ammunitions and guns, instead of agriculture commodities, went to Iraq under these loan programs. ``I'm horrified.''

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide Union Grievance Issue in California Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide in a case from California whether employers sometimes must submit a union's grievance to arbitration even though the complaint centers on a since-expired contract. The justices said they will review rulings that, if upheld, would force Litton Financial Printing Division, a subsidiary of Litton Industries Inc., to submit a 1980 dispute to arbitration. Litton prints blank checks at six plants, where employees are represented by the Printing Specialties District Council No. 2. In November 1980, Litton decided to close down the ``cold-type'' printing operation at its Santa Clara, Calif., plant and expand its ``hot-type'' operation there. The move sparked the laying off of 10 employees who had worked in the cold-type operation. The employees were not laid off on the basis of plantwide seniority. The collective bargaining agreement with the printers' union had expired in October 1979 - about 11 months before the layoff dispute arose. Litton was refusing to recognize or bargain with the union. The expired contract contained a grievance-arbitration procedure for resolving such disputes, and the union filed grievances for each of the 10 laid-off employees. Litton, noting that the contract had expired, refused to process the grievances. The union then filed unfair labor practice complaints with the National Labor Relations Board, and the board ruled that Litton had violated federal labor law. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the board's ruling last January. ``The board reasonably concluded that the layoff was a mandatory subject of bargaining and that Litton, therefore, violated (the National Labor Relations Act) by refusing to bargain about the layoff decision,'' the appeals court said. In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for Litton argued that just as the employer had no obligation to bargain over shutting down the cold-type printing operations in Santa Clara, it had no obligation to bargain over the resulting layoffs. ``There is no obligation ... to arbitrate seniority grievances based upon facts which occur long after contract expiration,'' the appeal said. Justice Department lawyers had urged the court to reject the appeal. The case is Litton Financial Printing Division vs. NLRB, 90-285.

DOC.HEAD: Court Asks Administration Views on Black Voting Rights in Arkansas
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today asked the Bush administration its views of whether a special federal court may protect black voting rights in Arkansas by forcing officials to get its approval before making election changes there. The court said it wants to hear from Justice Department lawyers before saying whether it will hear arguments by Arkansas officials that the three-judge panel improperly exceeded its authority. The government's response could take months. The three-judge court, by a 2-1 vote in May, ruled that state officials must get its approval before making changes affecting majority-vote requirements in the state's general elections. The lower court also said any plan to reapportion state legislative districts based on the 1990 census must be delayed for 60 days after a plan's adoption by a state apportionment board. The delay will allow time for any voting rights challenge to the new districts, the three-judge court said. The lower court invoked a so-called pre-clearance provision of the federal Voting Rights Act, giving federal courts power in some cases to review election changes in southern states. The pre-clearance authority is based on a finding that blacks were victims of deliberate voting rights abuses in the past, the three-judge court said - not merely that past practices unintentionally diluted black voting strength. The panel cited four such abuses in which the Arkansas Legislature hampered the ability of black candidates to win local offices. Black candidates who amassed pluralities in earlier elections lost after laws were changed to require majority victories in a runoff. ``Devotion to majority rule for local offices lay dormant as long as the plurality system produced white officeholders,'' the three-judge court said. ``But whenever black candidates used this system sucessfully ... the response was swift and certain. Laws were passed ... to close off this avenue of black political victory.'' The three-judge court said it credited testimony by Gov. Bill Clinton that the pace of political reform in Arkansas is quickening, and that the rights of blacks are being protected. But the lower court said the state's past record still warrants intervention by the federal courts. The Supreme Court has asked the Bush administration for its views in a related Arkansas case, in which black voters in a rural county challenged a majority-vote requirement for party primaries and countywide general elections. Lower courts have upheld the system. The case acted on today is Clinton vs. Jeffers, 90-394.

DOC.HEAD: Low Prices at Art Auction Indicate Deflated Market
DOC.TEXT: A sale of Impressionist and modern paintings from the estate of Henry Ford II brought $20 million less than expected, further proof that the air has been let out of the art market balloon. ``I think if it was held six months ago it would have gone better,'' said Sotheby's auctioneer John Marion after Monday's auction. Thirteen of the 36 artworks were not sold because bidding failed to meet the minimum price set by the seller. Of the 23 works sold, 13 went for less than the presale estimate. Tonight at Sotheby's, the art collection of the late Greta Garbo will go on the block, including three works by Auguste Renoir. The Ford collection included works by Paul Cezanne, Amedeo Modigliani, Henri Matisse, Joan Miro and Marc Chagall. The auction had been expected to fetch more than $50 million, but winning bids totaled just $30.43 million. Ford, who was vice chairman of Sotheby's from 1960 to 1980 and headed Ford Motor Co. from 1945 to 1980, died in 1987. He was the grandson of automobile magnate Henry Ford. Some blamed the low prices on the quality of the art. ``The Ford collection is not great,'' said Manhattan dealer Edward Nahem. Others blamed the falling market. ``Every speculator in any market likes to buy when it's going up,'' said Paris art dealer Mickey Tiroche. Marion even suggested that the Gulf conflict could be having an impact. ``There's nobody walking the earth that doesn't have some feeling about what's happening in the Middle East and there is no way it could not have some effect on buying,'' said Marion. Renoir's ``The Cup of Chocolate'' was auctioned apart from the rest of the Ford collection and fetched $18.15 million. The painting was valued at $15 million to $18 million. At Sotheby's sale of postwar art last week, only half the works offered sold. In contrast, the last few seasons saw paintings routinely sold at record-breaking prices. On Wednesday, Christie's auction house will offer a still life by Vincent Van Gogh, ``Vase With Daisies and Poppies,'' valued at $12 million to $16 million.

DOC.HEAD: Court Sets Aside Nebraska Man's Death Sentence
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today set aside a Nebraska murderer's death sentence, and ordered the state's highest court to restudy his case. The justices told the Nebraska Supreme Court to reconsider Randolph Reeves' sentence in light of their decision in a Mississippi case last March that gave state appeals courts greater authority to uphold such sentences. The court in that March ruling said state courts may uphold death sentences even if sentencing juries wrongly considered some adverse evidence. The justices said in the Mississippi case that state appeals courts are enpowered to reweigh aggravating and mitigating evidence in capital punishment cases without sending them back for new jury determinations. Reeves was convicted of the March 29, 1980, fatal stabbings of Janet Mesner and Victoria Lamm in Lincoln. The case is Reeves vs. Nebraska, 90-5659.

DOC.HEAD: European Farmers Protest GATT Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of European farmers, some wielding pitchforks and clanging cowbells, marched through the city today to protest efforts to cut agricultural subsidies at world trade talks. About 10,000 farmers demonstrated outside the administrative headquarters of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in Geneva, site of the talks on freeing commerce in farm products and 14 other areas. The farmers, mainly from France, Germany, Italy and Switzerland, carried signs denouncing the talks and singling out U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills for ``destroying European farmers.'' GATT farm talks were suspended after Washington and a group of allied farm exporting nations rejected as insufficient a European Community offer for cuts in state supports. France and Germany led opposition inside the 12-nation EC to offering even the proposal now on the table. ``Millions of family farms in Europe are threatened in their extistence due to the proposals at the GATT talks,'' a leaflet distributed by the demonstrators said. ``Free trade without barriers ... destroys structures oriented toward family farming, forces an industrialization of agriculture and creates instability on agrarian markets.'' The farmers said they do not oppose ``sensible adaptation'' and proposed ``an improved balance of markets'' in international agriculture. GATT Director-General Arthur Dunkel of Switzerland received a farmer delegation inside the trade organization's lakeside building. The marchers then continued through Geneva. No injuries were reported in the demonstration. Swiss police were out in force for the protest. Dunkel, who oversees the entire GATT talks, warned on Monday that plans to conclude an ambitious package of market-opening accords at a Dec. 3-7 ministerial meeting are ``now in jeopardy.'' In an emergency meeting of senior negotiators, he appealed to all sides to show more flexibility within a matter of days. U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said last week it would be ``a big mistake to even contemplate extending the negotiations.'' The United States and the Australian-led, 13-nation Cairns group, which also includes major Third World farm exporters, on Saturday refused negotiations on an EC offer to cut farm supports by 30 percent. The proposal provides for cuts in overall aid over 10 years backdated to 1986, thus giving the EC credit for mesaures already taken. There are no separate provisions for cutting export subsidies, which Washington has said it considers indispensable. The United States and the Cairns group are seeking cuts of 75 percent in domestic supports and import barriers, and 90 percent in export subsidies, spaced over 10 years with 1991 as base year.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Uncover 23 Skeletons in Residential Area
DOC.TEXT: Construction workers dug up 23 skeletons buried in a mass grave in the northwestern town of Most, the state news agency CTK reported Tuesday. The first skeleton was found Monday morning in a residential area of the town, 50 miles northwest of Prague. By Tuesday, 23 had been unearthed, the agency said. Experts estimate the skeletons were buried 25 to 50 years ago, CTK said, adding that all were males and relatively young when they died. The disordered positions of the skeletons indicated a mass grave rather than a regular burial place, CTK said.

DOC.HEAD: Funeral Home Will Bury or Marry
DOC.TEXT: Collins Funeral Home doesn't just want to bury its customers. It wants to marry them, too. The funeral home's Abundant Living Center, opening Sunday, will be offered as a place for weddings. The standard marriage vow, ``until death do us part,'' will take on a new meaning, said Collins vice president Annette Rollins. ``We wanted to go one step farther in providing a service to our customers,'' Rollins said Monday. ``We think it's a natural for us. We want to help a couple plan for the life ahead of them.'' And, of course, the afterlife as well. ``We want to be a part of more than just the final event in a person's life,'' said Rollins, a cousin of company president Mary A. Collins. Rollins said the 87-year-old funeral home got the idea from professional journals. ``We've read about this in other parts of the country,'' she said. ``Mary said she would like a way to help our customers and friends in more ways than just the death experience. We feel this is only proper.'' No weddings are scheduled yet in the new 250-seat center, but several have made inquiries. Customers who might balk at marrying in a building owned by a funeral home probably haven't considered that churches are used for both purposes, Rollins said. ``A church can be a happy place or a sad place - it depends on the occasion. This is the same.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Warns Against Plastic Wrap
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Ministry warned people Tuesday against covering fatty foods in plastic wrap or cooking foods covered in the clingy plastic that it said could cause cancer. In a ministry report, government scientists said foods with a high fat content, like cheese, cooked meats and butter, should not be wrapped in plastic film because the fat acts as a solvent releasing the plastic's chemicals into the food. The Ministry of Agriculture report called for toxicological studies on the chemicals used in food industry packaging. Consumer organizations recommended storing food in a bowl covered with a plate. The Consumers' Association appealed for warnings on plastic wrap boxes telling people not to wrap fatty foods in the film. The government report said the intake of the plasticizer DEHA used in PVC-based cling film has been substantially reduced and that the intake of the chemical acetyl tributyl citrate has increased because of the increased use of plastic wraps developed especially for microwaves.

DOC.HEAD: One Dead, Four Injured in Prison iot
DOC.TEXT: Rioting inmates took hostages in a prison in southeastern Spain, and one inmate was killed and four injured in the melee, Spanish National Radio reported Tuesday. The radio said details about the riot in the prison at Fontcale were sketchy, but it appeared that a group of 20 inmates still held five guards hostage Tuesday. Alicante Civil Governor Pedro Valdecantos said rioters complained of rough treatment by guards and also demanded that inmates suffering from AIDS be allowed to die outside the prison. Valdecantos said the rioters had released half the original 10 hostages they took Monday, including several primary-level school teachers who taught classes at the prison. The radio said the dead inmate had died of stab wounds and that the four men injured, some seriously, were being treated in local hospitals.

DOC.HEAD: Australia Widens Sea Boundaries
DOC.TEXT: The federal government said Tuesday it will extend its territorial sea limit from three nautical miles to 12 in an effort to better control its marine environment and resources. The decision, which takes effect Nov. 20, was announced jointly by Foreign Affairs Minister Gareth Evans and Attorney General Michael Duffy. They said the right to such an extension was ``well established'' internationally and that other countries, including the United States, had recently extended their territorial sea boundaries to 12 nautical miles. They gave no other reason for the extension. Australia already has a 200-nautical-mile fishing zone.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Frees 44 Egyptian POWs
DOC.TEXT: Iran on Tuesday freed 44 Egyptians captured while fighting alongside Iraqi troops during the 1980-88 Persian Gulf war, Tehran radio reported. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, said the prisoners were freed in response to a request by Egyptian theologians visiting Tehran. They were handed over to Sheik Mohammed Ghazali, a prominent Egyptian theologian. Egyptian press reports have estimated that Iran seized 13,000 to 20,000 Egyptians during the war. Hundreds of other Arabs, mainly Lebanese and Somali soldiers, also were captured before a U.N.-sponsored cease-fire halted hostilities in August 1988. After the cease-fire, Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani moved to end Iran's international isolation and improve ties with Arab and other countries. The prisoner release is seen as a gesture by Tehran to end more than a decade of acrimony with Cairo. It moved the two countries closer to the establishment of relations. Egypt granted asylumn to the late Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi after he was toppled by the Islamic Revolution in 1979. The shah died in Cairo in July 1980. Iran also is critical of Egypt's 1979 peace treaty with Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Too Much TV Linked to High Cholesterol in Kids
DOC.TEXT: Grade-school children who watch two hours of television a day are at increased risk of having high cholesterol levels, and the risk climbs the more they watch, researchers said Tuesday. Children watching television four hours a day are four times as likely to have high cholesterols as are children who watch less than two hours, the researchers reported. Previous research showed that children who watched too much television exercised less, were overweight and had bad diets. ``We made the next step - to look at TV and cholesterol,'' said Thomas K. Hei, who reported the findings at the annual meeting of the American Heart Association. ``The message is if you can't get your children to stop watching TV, maybe get them to exercise more and keep them from unhealthy food,'' said Hei, a student at the University of California, Irvine. The study of 1,077 suburban Southern California children demonstrated that television habits are the best clue to identifying children with high cholesterol, said Dr. Kurt V. Gold of the University of California, Irvine, who directed the study. In families with a history of heart disease or high cholesterol levels, television habits ``facilitated the identification of nine out of 10 of the children with cholesterol levels above 200,'' Gold said. ``It provides another tool to help us identify the many children with elevated blood cholesterol levels who might otherwise go undetected.'' Peggy Charren, the president of Action for Children's Television, blamed television commercials shown during children's shows. ``The food messages you get for children couldn't be worse,'' she said. ``We have never sold kids the foods that anyone wants them to eat. We sell candy, we sell high-fat snacks and we push fast-food restaurants.'' The average American child watches 23 hours of television per week, Charren said. The children in the study who watched two to four hours of television a day were average viewers. Hei and Gold found that the children's risk of having elevated cholesterol levels was 50 percent higher than children who watched less than two hours of television per day. The two researchers sent questionnaires to parents whose children had had their cholesterol tested. The questionnaires inquired about the children's television viewing habits and the family's history of heart disease. Nearly all of the chldren in the study were between ages 2 and 12, with an average age of 7, Hei said. They were mostly white and upper-middle class, he said. The American Academy of Pediatrics, which supported the study, says any child with a cholesterol level over 175 should be treated. ``Since cholesterol levels tend to rise somewhat when a child reaches adulthood, many of these children could have dangerously high levels in later life,'' Gold said. A level above 240 is considered high for adults, and levels between 200 and 240 are ``borderline high,'' according to the American Heart Association. ``It would be wonderful if you could buy a TV set that only operates when the people watching it are exercising,'' Gold said.

DOC.HEAD: Monterey Looks for Federal Law to Help Evict Sea Lions
DOC.TEXT: The Monterey harbor has become a sort of Sea Lion Motel where the sardines are plenty and the living is easy. But the pinnipeds may soon face eviction as officials renew their fight to roust the mammals. City officials hope to drive away the mammals by enforcing a proposed amendment to a 1972 federal law that protects sea lions from harm. The change, which could go into effect early next year, would make it illegal to feed marine mammals, putting an end to concessionaires selling sea lion snacks that tourists have used to lure the animals to shore. ``To the average Joe, the sea lions look like something out of a Walt Disney movie, but until you go down to the docks and stand right next to one of these monsters, it's hard to understand what the city is dealing with,'' said Mitch Whippern, administrative assistant for the Monterey Public Facilities Department. Most of the hundreds of sea lions who gather off the Monterey coast sun themselves on rocks about a football field away from the harbor. But tourists have lured dozens of the animals to the wharf and onto floating boat slips - to the dismay of city officials and fishermen. A dozen of the 300- to 800-pound mammals recently climbed on a tugboat and sank it. Others have prevented some boat owners from docking. The city has spent $40,000 so far this year repairing sea lion damage at the docks. Whippern said city officials have tried to scare away the sea lions by spraying them with high pressure hoses, banging together garbage cans, hitting brooms against the docks and using an ultrasonic whistle. ``If we had a guy out there with a hose all day we could keep them off, but if you leave for a minute they come right back,'' Whippern said.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Farm Credit System Was Reckless In Lending Policy
DOC.TEXT: A report financed by the American Bankers Association said Tuesday the cooperatively owned Farm Credit System fueled a land boom in the 1970s that ultimately led to hard times in the 1980s. The report said a 1971 law liberalizing collateral requirements for farm real estate loans made by the system ``unleashed a boom in land prices in rural America that saw the inflation-adjusted value of farmland nearly double from 1971 to 1980,'' But the report added, ``This land boom was unsustainable, and the bubble burst in 1980. By 1986, six years later, the average real value of farmland had dropped back almost to its 1971 level.'' The 1971 law raised the system's collateral limit to 85 percent of the market value of farmland from the previous standard of 65 percent of its agricultural income-producing value. The report, ``The Farm Credit System: Reckless Lender to Rural America,'' was prepared for the American Bankers Association by Ely & Company Inc., an Alexandria, Va., financial consulting firm. Ron Erickson, a spokesman for the Farm Credit Administration, which oversees the system, said he had not seen the report. But Erickson said it has been widely known and talked about for years that ``during the '70s when commodity prices were good and land values were inflating, farmers were eager to expand and were borrowing heavily to do so. They were basing that - and so were the lenders - on inflated land values.'' Erickson added in a telephone interview from his office in McLean, Va., that the boost in the lending limit allowed by the 1971 law was an important signal. In fact, he said, the previous lending limit of 65 percent of farmland's agricultural value was ``usually around 50 percent'' of the land's market value. Thus, the increase to 85 percent of market value was, in effect, even greater in many cases. Bert Ely, president of the consulting firm, said Tuesday in remarks prepared for a conference in Denver, Colo., sponsored by the bankers, that the Farm Credit System unwisely used its new powers in the 1970s to overlend to American farmers. Ely said the ensuing financial crunch on farmers will ultimately cost taxpayers about $100 billion. ``As a result of the damage caused by FCS overlending, federal government payments to farmers in the 1982-89 period exceeded the earlier eight-year period by $75 billion, measured in 1990 dollars,'' he said. ``Future government payments to farmers plus losses suffered by the Farmers Home Administration account for the balance of this $100 billion fiasco,'' Ely added. The Farm Credit System, which includes federal land bank associations and other lending entities, is traditionally subject to federal government oversight. But it ran into huge financial difficulties in the early 1980s, with Congress in 1987 passing a package of reforms and financial bailout. Ely said the 1987 reforms, however, did not roll back the collateral liberalization of the 1971 law. ``Therefore,'' he said, ``the FCS still has the power to overlend again to American farmers and to spark yet another farmland boom (and) bust.''

DOC.HEAD: Supporters of Pro-Democracy Activists Clash With Police
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UDPATE with witnesses saying youth shot, more rioting after adjournment. Pickup 10th graf pvs, `Before the...'
DOC.HEAD: ssociated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Paramilitary riot police fired tear gas and live ammunition to disperse more than 1,000 supporters of pro-democracy activists who went on trial today for allegedly holding an illegal political meeting. The trial was adjourned, and the magistrate demanded an explanation for the police action. At least 14 people were arrested, and one witness said a youth was shot in the leg and that other people suffered minor injuries and the effects of tear gas. Hundreds of baton-wielding police, some on horseback, fought running battles with supporters outside the small courthouse in this farming center 175 miles southwest of the capital, Lusaka. Rioting spread to a nearby shopping district, where the windows of several stores were smashed. Witnesses said at least four stores were looted of electrical goods and foodstuffs. Some rioters wearing T-shirts with pro-democracy inscriptions chanted political slogans and hurled stones at police. Other rioters urged police to disobey their commanders. On trial were labor leader Frederick Chiluba and eight colleagues in the Movement for Multiparty Democracy. After police fired warning shots into the air, Magistrate Sylvester Simachela adjourned the trial and demanded an explanation from state prosecutors. State prosecutors told Simachela that police opened fire in self-defense after crowds began throwing stones. At that, the public benches in the court erupted in shouts of ``Liar, liar!'' ``I don't think there is any court in the country that can sit with these gunshots going on outside,'' the magistrate told the court, packed to capacity by about 100 spectators. New rioting broke out later in the afternoon. It was not clear when the hearing would resume. Before the adjournment, Chiluba, head of the powerful Zambia Congress of Trade Unions, and his eight fellow pro-democracy activists pleaded innocent to conducting illegal political activities. They were charged with convening an illegal meeting in Choma on Oct. 16 and belonging to an illegal political organization. Both charges carry a maximum penalty of six months in jail. Attorneys for the pro-democracy leaders say they will argue that the Oct. 16 meeting and the existence of the pro-democracy movement are protected by freedom of association clauses in the constitution. Zambia has a one-party system imposed by President Kenneth Kaunda in 1973. He has promised to hold multiparty elections next year. But proposed constitutional changes allowing the formation of new political organizations is not scheduled for debate by legislators until Nov. 20. Pro-democracy activists in Choma accused the police of provoking today's rioting to discredit their supporters. Kaunda has frequently argued that a multiparty system would lead to unrest touched off by tribal rivalries.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Rejects Wisconsin School Choice Law
DOC.TEXT: State legislators erred when they passed a law that allows poor students in Milwaukee to attend private schools using state funds, an appeals court ruled today. The 4th District Court of Appeals in Madison said it was unconstitutional because the law was passed as part of the state budget. The court said that violated a provision in the state constitution designed to prevent bills benefiting local interests from being ``smuggled'' through the Legislature. The court did not directly address the merits of the school choice program. The program, passed last spring and begun this fall, allows parents to send their children to non-sectarian, private schools with state funds. The program was authorized to provide a $2,500 stipend each for as many as 1,000 students this year, but only about 400 were able to enroll in about 10 eligible private schools because of space limitations. The money for the program comes from state aid provided to the Milwaukee Public Schools system, which has about 97,000 students.
