The program is the first in the nation to directly provide parents with a voucher to allow them to send their students out of public schools and into private institutions. Critics charge it undermines public education and benefits only a few while ignoring the majority of students left behind in declining public schools. Roger Sundby, assistant to state Schools Superintendent Herbert Grover, said the program will continue for at least 30 days to allow for further appeals. Sundby said the state Department of Public Instruction, which has opposed the program, considered the ruling a victory but would have preferred a ruling on the program's merits.

DOC.HEAD: Mitterrand Gives Two Picasso Paintings to Spanish Leader
DOC.TEXT: President Francois Mitterrand on Tuesday gave two paintings by Spanish-born artist Pablo Picasso to President Felipe Gonzalez of Spain. ``This gesture affirms one more time the links of friendship between our two peoples,'' Mitterrand said. The two works, ``The Rooftops of Barcelona'' painted in 1903, and ``Homage to Spaniards Killed For France,'' finished in 1947, made up part of the artist's personal collection. Picasso, who died in 1973 at age 91, spent most of his life in France. But he asked his heirs to return the two paintings to his native country. The donation was worked out between Picasso's estate and the French government to circumvent strict laws forbidding the export of art works from France. ``The Rooftops of Barcelona,'' from the artist's celebrated blue period, will go on display at the Picasso Museum in Barcelona. The other painting goes to the Prado in Madrid. The donation came at a summit meeting between the two leaders on their policies on European unity and the Persian Gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Predict Many More Heart Transplants for Children
DOC.TEXT: The number of children receiving heart transplants is likely to increase substantially as doctors find new uses for this dramatic surgery and overcome a critical shortage of organs, physicians predict. Doctors at the annual meeting of the American Heart Association also said the outlook for young heart transplant patients is improving, largely because of better ways to prevent their bodies from rejecting the new organs. The use of heart transplants, especially in the very young, grew quickly during the past decade. In 1979, doctors performed just one of these operations in children. By 1989, there were 187 operations at 58 hospitals around the world. ``I think the number will become much larger,'' said Dr. David Baum of Stanford University. ``Transplantation in the very young will become a more widely accepted procedure, especially as survival is increased.'' Until now, heart transplants in the young have been reserved largely for children with a muscle disease called cardiomyopathy. But several doctors said the procedure is being expanded to children with severe heart birth defects. ``As our success continues to improve and as patients' chances for lifelong survival increase, we are starting to perform transplants for conditions in which there are other surgical interventions,'' said Dr. Daniel Bernstein, another Stanford physician. Until recently, doctors' only option for youngsters with misformed hearts was to try to fix the abnormality surgically. But the operations are often very risky and doctors believe that replacing the heart entirely may be safer for some young patients. Bernstein said Stanford doctors have performed 20 transplants in youngsters with birth defects, and are ``extremely encouraged.'' Among the best known young transplant recipients was Stormie Jones, who received a new heart and liver in the same operation in 1984. The girl died Sunday at age 13 after developing problems with her transplanted organs. One of her physicians, Dr. David Bilheimer of the University of Texas in Dallas, said she would have died years ago without the transplants. ``There is not anything else we could have done for her,'' he said. ``For five years, she had an excellent quality of life.'' As heart transplants become more routine, patients' survival has increased. At Stanford, for instance, 75 percent of patients are still alive one year after their operations, and 70 percent survive at least five years. The improvement in the survival of transplant patients, including children, results largely from the discovery of cyclosporine, a drug that keeps the body from rejecting the foreign organ. Dr. F. Jay Fricker of Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh said doctors there have treated 12 young patients with an experimental new drug called FK506, which he said in preliminary use appears to work better than cyclosporine. But a shortage of donor organs continues to limit the number of operations. Dr. Mark Boucek of Loma Linda University said 40,000 children whose organs could be donated die each year, but less than half of 1 percent of their organs are offered for transplants. ``If we could have a yield of 2 percent of all deaths, we would probably be able to satisfy all of the babies who could benefit from transplants,'' Boucek said. But Baum said he believes the situation is improving, in part as more doctors and parents become willing to suggest using the organs of young victims. Also, he said doctors are finding better ways to preserve organs so they can be transported farther. And they are also finding ways to keep young patients alive with mechanical pumping devices until donated organs arive. He noted that many insurance commpany also have recently agreed to routinely pay for children's heart transplants and that should make the procedure more widely available.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Threatens To Appoint Government Defense Lawyers for Noriega
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with hearing today, judge threatening to appoint government-paid attorneys. Picks up 9th graf, `The defense ...' DELETES first reference to Rubino in peniultimate graf to conform.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge, frustrated by delays in paying Manuel Noriega's attorneys, said today he will appoint two government-paid defense attorneys if their fee problem is not resolved by Friday. ``It is obvious that we simply may not be able to unfreeze any money,'' U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler said during a hearing on the fees. In June, Hoeveler ordered prosecutors to unfreeze about $6 million in 27 Noriega-linked bank accounts for use by the Noriega's private lawyers. But five months later, defense lawyers have not received a penny, and today they asked Hoeveler to light a fire under the U.S. government and banks in France, Switzerland and Austria, to release the funds. But Justice Department attorney Drew Arena told the judge that the foreign governments had frozen the accounts for their own investigations and have so far refused to release them despite the U.S. government's request. The problem is the United States had alleged the money was drug proceeds, but was now reversing course by asking that it be given to Noriega, Arena said. ``It's rather, your honor, like trying to `unring' a bell,'' Arena said. Lead defense attorney Frank Rubino accused the U.S. State Department of undermining efforts to unfreeze the funds by encouraging foreign governments to act on their own. Hoeveler, however, said he was frustrated by the delays and wanted the case to proceed as quickly as possible. The judge has agreed that the trial will not begin Jan. 28, but said it will not be delayed by much. Under the law covering court-appointed counsel, the attorneys could receive only a maximum of $60 an hour, far less than the $350 an hour Noriega's attorneys have said they needed. Meanwhile, Noriega and Cable News Network have agreed to let the U.S. Supreme Court decide whether the deposed Panamanian dictator's tape-recorded conversations with his lawyers can be broadcast. CNN aire excerpts of one tape over the weekend in defiance of Hoeveler. The defense and the network agreed Monday to suspend their feud until the U.S. Supreme Court decides whether CNN's free-press rights outweigh Noriega's right to a fair trial. The network planned to file the appeal this week. ``I will be interested in seeing what the Supreme Court will do in this novel situation,'' Hoeveler said. The Atlanta-based network agreed not to play any of the disputed tapes until the Supreme Court rules. In return, Noriega's defense delayed a request for contempt penalties of up to $300,000 per broadcast against the network, and Hoeveler stayed his order that CNN hand over seven disputed tapes to the court. CNN attorney Terry Bienstock said the network had the right to play other Noriega tapes as long as they did not include conversations with his attorneys. The judge agreed. CNN defied Hoeveler by broadcasting on Friday and Saturday an excerpt of a tape in which Noriega spoke in Spanish with a defense attorney's secretary, who translated for his defense team. On the tape, Noriega speculated that the government would use as witnesses against him two Panamanians in U.S. custody. Rubino has said he will seek dismissal of all charges against Noriega, alleging government misconduct in recording the calls made from the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside Miami. Noriega has been held there since his surrender to U.S. forces shortly after the invasion of Panama in December. He is accused of accepting $4.6 million in bribes to protect the cocaine trade.

DOC.HEAD: Court Throws Out Murder Conviction of Louisiana Man
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 6-7, Agreed to hear, with other case.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today threw out the murder conviction of a Louisiana man because the jury that convicted him was given an impermissible definition of ``beyond a reasonable doubt.'' The justices unanimously ruled that Tommy Cage, currently an inmate on Louisiana's death row, is entitled to a new trial. In other action, the court: - Set aside a ruling that let Louisiana officials give mind-altering drugs to a convicted mass murderer in the hope he could be made sane enough to execute. The justices ordered a state court to restudy its ruling in the case of death row inmate Michael Owen Perry. The one-paragraph, unsigned opinion ordered reconsideration of the case in light of a Supreme Court opinion in February permitting prison officials to force inmates to take powerful anti-psychotic drugs without a judge's consent. - Agreed to hear an appeal by a Maryland man who said a federal judge illegally increased his sentence. The justices said they will use the case of Thomas Braxton to decide whether federal judges may base stiffer sentences on a charge that was dismissed. - Turned down the bid of an Ohio legislator, Robert E. Netzley, to avoid a libel lawsuit for using the term ``Mafia'' in opposing the re-election of James P. Celebrezze to the state's highest court. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that Netzley, a Republican member of the Ohio House of Representatives from Miami County, must defend himself against Celebrezze's lawsuit. - Turned away an effort by Tom Perdue, onetime top aide to Georgia Gov. Joe Frank Harris, to kill a libel lawsuit against him by state Public Service Commission member J. Mac Barber. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that Barber's allegations that Perdue falsely accused him of bribery should go to a jury. Cage had been convicted of fatally shooting Arthur Johnson while robbing him of a gold chain and medallion on a New Orleans street corner April 16, 1986. Cage had been sentenced to death for the crime. Jurors who convicted Cage were told they had to conclude he was guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. The judge said, ``This doubt, however, must be a reasonable one; that is one that is founded upon a real tangible substantial basis and not upon mere caprice and conjecture. It must be such doubt as would give rise to a grave uncertainty ... What is required is not an absolute or mathematical certainty, but a moral certainty.'' The Louisiana Supreme Court, in upholding Cage's conviction and death sentence, said the jury instruction was constitutionally permissible when taken in its complete context. But today the nation's highest court said the state court was wrong. ``It is plain to us that the words `substantial' and `grave' as they are commonly understood suggest a higher degree of doubt than is required for acquittal under the reasonable doubt standard,'' the justices said in an unsigned opinion. ``A reasonable juror could have interpreted the instruction to allow a finding of guilt based on a degree of proof below that required by the (Constitution's) due process clause,'' the justices said. The case is Cage vs. Louisiana, 89-7302.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Senators Call for Special Session of Congress on Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Dole joining Lugar, White House rejecting the suggestion. Pickup 4th, `In other...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AMM1,3,WX7,NY6
DOC.TEXT: Two senior Republican senators today called for a special session of Congress to authorize action against Iraq, and Saddam Hussein's chief deputy flew to Morroco to discuss an Arab attempt to avert war in the Persian Gulf. Sen. Richard Lugar, R.-Ind., said a congressional vote would give Saddam and the world another signal that President Bush's gulf policies have overwhelming American support and that his threats of force are ``credible.'' Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole called for a ``declaration of support and a willingness to commit whatever resources it takes to fulfill the mission.'' A Democratic critic of Bush's decision to send 200,000 more troops to the gulf agreed that Congress needs to play a greater role in the crisis. But the White House rejected the idea of a special session of Congress. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We don't think that's necessary ... there is no war.'' He also said the president believes he has consulted sufficiently with members of Congress and will continue to do so. In other developments today: -Former U.S. Attorney General Ramsey Clark said Iraq will release four more American hostages. Clark spoke in Amman, the Jordanian capital, after concluding an independent peace mission to Baghdad. Danish radio said Iraq also agreed today to release some of the 38 Danish hostages held in Baghdad. -President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt made a surprise trip to Libya and met leader Moammar Gadhafi for talks on the gulf situation. The visit came a day after Deputy Premier Saadoun Hammadi of Iraq held talks with Gadhafi. -British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said she believes Saddam is close to acquiring nuclear weapons. Speaking in the House of Commons, she reiterated that force must be used unless Iraq ends its 3-month-old occupation of Kuwait. -Cable News Network reported that Iraq may have used kickbacks paid by American companies to purchase weapons it used in the Kuwaiti invasion. CNN also said Monday Iraq diverted millions of dollars from U.S. Department of Agriculture-backed loans to buy trucks and other hardware used in the invasion. There was no immediate comment from the Bush administration on the report. Regarding the call by Lugar today, Bush refused to comment on whether a special session of Congress was needed when questioned by a reporter at the start of a Cabinet meeting this morning. Lugar, speaking on the NBC's Today show, said: ``I think the president must lay out now to the nation and the Congress specifically what our aims are. ``And then he must call for a session of the Congress and set a date for the return of the Congress to debate those issues and vote, affirmatively I would presume, so that we have authorization for what is required.'' Lugar, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said he was not suggesting what form an authorization vote should take. ``It occurs to me congressional leaders and the president can agree upon an authorization, but clearly the president needs to have an up-and-down vote by members of the Congress representing the people of this country, so that our unity is clear, our staying power is clear and the people around the world, friend and foe alike, know that we are in this.'' Sen. Sam Nunn, who publicly questioned Bush's decision to deploy another 200,000 troops to the gulf, agreed ``the Congress should be involved here.'' ``If there ever is a casebook example of the constitutional power of congress to declare war, this is it,'' the Georgia Democrat and chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said on the same program. Before leaving Baghdad for Morocco, Iraq's first deputy prime minister, Taha Yassin Ramadan, said he was carrying a letter from Saddam to the Moroccan leader, King Hassan II, noting the ``dangers facing the Arabs'' by the gulf crisis, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. Morocco has contributed 1,700 troops to the multinational force that has massed in the Saudi desert following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, but the nation has maintained contact with the Iraqi leadership. Ramadan said Baghdad ``supports any serious Arab effort on any level that will serve the interests of the Arab nation.'' But he said Arab summits ``should not be forums at which the American Pentagon's policies are translated into Arabic.'' He repeated the three conditions Iraq has set for attending such a meeting: that Iraq is consulted in advance on the agenda; the timing and location are chosen so that Saddam will be able to attend, and the agenda also include all Middle East issues, including the Palestine question. Saddam has insisted on tying his withdrawal from Kuwait to Israel's pulling back from the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

DOC.HEAD: `Cop Rock' Splits Network Scene, Replace `Equal Justice'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with replacement named. Picks up 4th graf, `The statement...'. ADDS one graf at end with more on replacement.
DOC.TEXT: The singing police squad of ABC's `op Rock'' will warble its last verse on Dec. 26. Cancellation rumors have circulated for weeks, but ABC steadfastly denied them until Monday, when it issued a statement announcing the decision. ABC today said ``Equal Justice,'' a one-hour legal drama about the professional and private lives of prosecutors, will take over the Wednesday night slot. ``Cop Rock,'' the bizarre melding of musical and gritty police drama got weak ratings despite decent reviews. The statement quoted entertainment president Robert Iger as saying the series' creator, Steven Bochco, ``delivered a daring and brilliantly produced series, one all of us at ABC are proud to be associated with.'' Bochco, who also created ``Hill Street Blues'' and ``L.A. Law,'' called ``Cop Rock'' the most brilliant thing he's ever done. ``I've never felt more supported by a network,'' he said. ``The truth is, I'm not going to go off and pout. I'm not mad at anybody. We work and live in a very commercial and intensely competitive world.'' ``Cop Rock'' made its premiere this fall with a blend of singing cops, a mayor on the take, an officer who dispensed with a cop killer by murdering him and a drug addict who sold her baby for a fix. Since its Sept. 26 debut, the series dropped to the bottom third of the A.C. Nielsen Co. rankings. Asked why viewers did not like the show, Bochco said, ``I don't know. It ain't medicine. If they don't like it, you can't force them to watch it.'' The executive producer, who also has the hit comedy ``Doogie Howser, M.D.'' on ABC, has a development deal with the network for eight more shows, including an animated, prime-time program for next year called ``Critters.'' ``Equal Justice,'' which first aired last season as a midseason replacement, will return to ABC's schedule on Jan. 9, Iger said today. The series' executive producer, Thomas Carter, won an Emmy Award for directing the pilot episode.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Lawmakers in Private Visit, First Since Crackdown
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 3rd pvs, `U.S. Embassy...' to UPDATE with State Dept. giving names of other delegation members. Pickup 4th, `The officials..'
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng met today with the first U.S. lawmakers to visit China since the military's violent suppression of the pro-democracy movement in June 1989. The U.S. Embassy refused to release any information about the delegation except to confirm it was led by Rep. Michael Oxley, R-Ohio. Oxley's office in Washington said the visit was private. U.S. Embassy spokesman Sheridan Bell confirmed Xinhua's report that the members of Congress were in China as guests of the Far East Studies Institute of the Chinese People's Institute of Foreign Affairs. He refused to provide other details. The State Department identified the other four congressmen on the trip as Reps. Jim Ross Lightfoot, R-Iowa; John J. Rhodes III, R-Ariz., E. Clay Shaw Jr., R-Fla., and George ``Buddy'' Darden, D-Ga. The official news agency Xinhua said Li told the delegation that China wants improved relations with the United States. The lawmakers and Li also discussed the Persian Gulf crisis, developments involving North and South Korea, and the future of Hong Kong, it said. The visit was the lead item on the state-run evening television news, pointing to the importance placed on it by Chinese officials. Washington's relations with Beijing have improved recently, in large part due to China's cooperation with the United States and others in the coalition opposing Iraq's Saddam Hussein, who seized Kuwait on Aug. 2. U.S.-Chinese ties were badly strained by the 1989 crackdown, in which the army opened fire on student-led demonstrators urging democratic reforms. Hundreds and possibly thousands of people were killed. The United States and other Western countries halted high-level visits to China in protest. The ban has not been lifted, but it applies only to the executive branch and not to members of Congress. President Bush made an exception to the ban when he sent national security adviser Brent Scowcroft to China for talks, and Secretary of State James A. Baker III has met with Foreign Minister Qian Qichen outside of China. American businessmen, investors and local officials have begun returning to China, but in numbers far below the pre-crackdown level. Li told the congressional delegation that China continues to seek better relations with the United States but urged non-interference in one another's affairs, Xinhua said. ``We Chinese should not observe the U.S. From the viewpoint of our own ideas and norms, while the Americans should not observe China's affairs according to their views and values,'' Li said. Xinhua also reported that a parliamentary delegation from Canada was visiting Beijing.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Hits Plan to Allow Lay People to Conduct Funerals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 14 grafs new with opposition to proposal; picks up 7th graf pvs, Among changes.
DOC.TEXT: A wave of opposition arose today to a proposal before U.S. Roman Catholic bishops that would allow lay people to conduct funeral services when clergy aren't available. A succession of disapproving speeches at a meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops left the plan in doubt. Bishop Elden F. Curtiss of Helena, Mont., said such a step would send a ``wrong signal'' that the church is ``moving from an ordained to a non-ordained ministry.'' ``The time when people most want a priest is when they are dying, at death and afterward,'' he said. Results of a ballot vote on the measure were to be disclosed in late afternoon. While a big proportion of the floor debate consisted of criticism of the proposal, several bishops strongly supported it. Archbishop Francis T. Hurley of Anchorage, Alaska, where ``extreme distances'' and ``extreme weather'' accent the need for lay people conducting funeral rites, said: ``It would be corporately narrow-minded and short-sighted not to allow this provision for the pastoral needs of people at one of their most poignant moments, the time of death.'' Under present rules, ordained ministers are required to preside at funeral litugies, but a worsening shortage of priests has brought requests that the task be opened to lay persons. Of 45 dioceses where there are some Sunday services without priests, a report said 17 have received requests to let lay people conduct funerals, and 18 see a pastoral need for it. The proposed change would authorize local bishops to permit it if they choose. However, such lay-led services could not include celebration of Holy Communion, for which priests are required. On the second day of their four-day annual fall meeting, the bishops also weighed moves to straighten out misimpressions given by some Bible readings in worship. Rephrasing of both sexually exclusive and politically stereotyping connotations were under consideration. Among changes proposed for a new lectionary, or cycle of liturgical Bible readings, were these: Replacing ``brothers'' with ``brothers and sisters,'' using ``people'' instead of the generic ``man'' and ``Jewish leaders'' or ``authorities'' instead of the blanket perjorative, ``the Jews.'' Archbishop John F. Whealan of Hartford, Conn., a Scripture scholar, said the changes went ``only so far as the original Hebrew and Greek texts allow.'' He said the variations were recommended from usages contained in a Catholic-produced translation, the New American Bible. He noted such changes were included in the recently published New Revised Standard Version, sponsored by the interdenominational National Council of Churches. Like that version, the changes would retain ``Father,'' ``Son'' and ``Holy Spirit'' in describing the trinity, the Christian view of one God's triune nature. ``While God is neither male nor female, the use of the masculine pronoun may sometimes be preferred in order to be faithful to the biblical text,'' the proposed document says. But it emphasized that words such as ``men,'' ``sons'' and ``brethren,'' once understood as inclusive generic terms, now often are understood as referring only to males. ``Their use has become ambiguous and is increasingly seen to exclude women,'' the paper says, stressing that words should not be used ``which deny the common dignity of all the baptized.'' After calling on the U.S. to exercise restraint to limit civilian casualties in any military operation in the Middle East, the bishops slated more discussion of that issue Wednesday. But this was to be in a closed-door session as moved by Cardinal Bernard Law of Boston and approved by a close vote of 126 to 118. Several bishops, including two from Alaska, Bishops Michael Kenny of Juneau and Francis Hurley of Anchorage, urged unsuccessfully that the discussion be open to the press and other observers. But the closed session may produce a further public statement about the Persian Gulf situation. The bishops' initial joint assessment came in affirming a letter sent last week by Archbishop Roger Mahony of Los Angeles to U.S. Secretary of State James Baker. It condemned Iraq's aggression and ``brutal treatment'' of civilians and said there was a ``clear need to resist'' it. But citing the church's age-old ``just war'' theory, the bishops said any military operation must be in proportion to ``the evil to be overcome'' and must rule out tactics targeting civilian populations. It thus would have to be a ``limited war, raising...the price to be paid,'' the bishops said, urging the U.S. to ``stay the course of persistent, peaceful and determined'' efforts.

DOC.HEAD: Court Allows `Mafia' Libel Suit to Stand
With AM-Scotus Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Tuesday rejected the appeal of an Ohio legislator being sued for libel because he used the term ``Mafia'' in opposing the re-election of an Italian-American to the state's highest court. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling that Robert E. Netzley, a Republican member of the Ohio House of Representatives, must defend himself at trial against a lawsuit by James P. Celebrezze, the former state court justice. In a separate case, the court also refused to kill a libel lawsuit against Tom Perdue, onetime top aide to Georgia Gov. Joe Frank Harris. In that suit, state Public Service Commission member J. Mac Barber says Perdue falsely accused of bribery. In the Ohio case, Celebrezze was an associate justice of the Ohio Supreme Court from January 1983 through December 1984. A Democrat, he was defeated in a 1984 election by Republican Craig Wright. At the time, Celebrezze's brother, Frank D. Celebrezze, was chief justice of the Ohio Supreme Court. His cousin, Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr., was the state's attorney general. Anthony Celebrezze was the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for governor this month. Netzley, chairman of the Miami County Republican Committee, prepared the campaign pamphlet over which James Celebrezze sued. The pamphlet, generally endorsing Republican candidates for various offices, stated: ``It's no wonder that some are calling Ohio's Justice System the `Mafia Family' Court. Take a look. Frank Celebrezze, Chief Justice, Brother Jimmy Celebrezze, Associate Justice, Cousin Tony Celebrezze, Ohio Attorney General, and Frank Celebrezze's `Crony' Angelo Gagliardi, intimidator in charge of the Ohio Disciplinary Council.'' In his lawsuit, Celebrezze contends that no other person had ever referred to the Ohio Supreme Court members as a Mafia family and that Netzley knew none of those mentioned in the pamphlet was in any way connected with the Mafia or organized crime. A state appeals court, ruling that the pamphlet was an expression of opinion, threw out the suit. But the Ohio Supreme Court, its ranks bolstered by substitute judges who had no conflict of interest in the case, voted 5-2 in May to reinstate it. The state court said the judge's denial of the dismissal requests could not be appealed until after a trial was conducted. In the Georgia case, the state's Public Service Commission was the target of a bribery investigation in 1984 and 1985. Barber was never charged with a crime as a result of that investigation, but others were indicted. Barber resigned from the commission in 1985 but ran in 1986 for the seat he had left 18 months earlier. He lost to Gary Andrews, the man appointed to succeed him. Barber regained a commission seat in elections this month. During the 1986 campaign, Perdue sent a letter to about 350 city and county officials throughout the state urging them to oppose Barber's election. In the letter, Perdue said: ``A Public Service Commissioner betrayed the public trust ... by accepting what amounted to a bribe.'' The letter added: ``When confronted with the fact that the attorney general and the Georgia Bureau of Investigation had this information and were about to seek a felony indictment, Mac Barber chose to resign his office rather than face the prospect of indictment and conviction. The trucking company official who gave Mac Barber the money was convicted and fined a total of $12,000.'' A state trial judge threw out Barber's suit, ruling that there was no ``actual malice'' - knowledge or reckless disregard of falsity. But the Georgia Court of Appeals reinstated the suit by a 5-4 vote last year.

DOC.HEAD: Teacher Accused of 30 Years of Molestations Faces Sentencing
DOC.TEXT: A teacher built a reputation of selflessness and devotion in more than 30 years in this ranching region. But he also left a legacy of molested male students - some of whose fathers say he also abused them. Douglas Marks, 63, is to be sentenced Wednesday in this Rocky Mountain community between Helena and Butte, ending a trail of crime and government inaction that stretches into the 1950s. When Marks pleaded guilty July 9 to four counts of felony sexual assault for molesting four elementary school boys, the fathers of two of the boys were in the courtroom. Both men said they, too, had been victims of Marks. A Jefferson County sheriff's deputy who received the complaint that set off the investigation said he had been a victim 25 years earlier. Marks faces up to 20 years on each count. Court records cite 22 molestation accusations dating to 1956, most too old to prosecute. County Attorney Rich Llewellyn says he has found 45 victims. Marks was removed from a teaching job in Boulder in 1959 after three students accused him of molesting them. He found another teaching job the next year in Clancy, about 20 miles away, then was rehired at Boulder Elementary School in 1965. In 1984, a young man, Paul Myrhow, came forward against Marks. It was more than five years before Marks was finally charged and all four of the offenses to which Marks pleaded guilty occurred after Myrhow's complaint. Many in this ranching-timbering town of 1,400 are quick to recount Marks' decades of generosity. Two sections of the high school were dedicated to him, and wall plaques - quietly removed after his plea - extolled ``his years of service to the community.'' Marks' family owns substantial ranch property in the Helena-Boulder area and a lumber mill in Clancy. A brother, Robert Marks, was a state legislator from 1969-1989, speaker of the Montana House in 1981-82 and 1987-88, and Republican leader in 1977-78, 1983-84 and 1985-86. Bob Laumeyer, school superintendent from 1970 to 1987, said Marks made many donations to the school anonymously by reducing his salary several hundred dollars a year. Marks also paid for poor students to take school trips and attend basketball camps, recalled Dick Nordon, Jefferson County High School's basketball coach. ``He liked to take students who didn't get many other chances to experience these things,'' he said. Three victims said that was how Marks found the boys he would molest. The school board has set aside $3,000 and promised more if necessary to provide counseling for any victims who request it. It also hired investigators to check allegations that some teachers and other school officials ignored complaints about Marks. The school board forced Marks to take an indefinite leave from the high school in December 1959 after three students accused him of molesting them. He and one of the students were living in a former school dormitory for out-of-town single teachers. The Boulder board took Marks back in 1965 because ``he was a wonderful teacher and highly thought of - even though there were doubts about his morals,'' said Wahle Phelen, a member of the board at the time. It was 1984 when Myrhow told his former Boy Scout leader, Deputy Sheriff Daryl Craft, that he had had a homosexual relationship with Marks for eight years. Craft told the Helena Independent Record that he, too, had been molsted by Marks. Craft said he took Myrhow to Sheriff Tom Dawson, but nothing happened. Dawson and state investigators have refused to comment. Myrhow, now 23, went public this summer after Marks pleaded guilty. In June 1989, Myrhow turned to Phillip Pallister, a physician who had helped force Marks out of Boulder in 1959 - but also had helped him keep the job at Clancy when some parents protested. Pallister said he had learned more about pedophiles by 1989 - and had discovered that some members of his own family had become victims of Marks. Pressed by Pallister and others, county attorney Llewellyn called in the state attorney general's office, but discovered months later that nothing had been done. He hired his own investigator, a social worker with experience in child-abuse cases, and filed charges in February.

DOC.HEAD: Dole, Lugar Urge Special Congressional Session on Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts grafs 5-8, Senate Majority, with Mitchell, Sasser comments. Editing throughout to shorten.
DOC.TEXT: Two key Republican senators urged President Bush today to call a special session of Congress to approve U.S. military action in the Persian Gulf. The White House rejected the idea. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We don't think that's necessary ... there is no war.'' Neither Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole nor Sen. Richard Lugar called for a formal declaration of war against Iraq's Saddam Hussein. But Dole said he wants a ``declaration of support and a willingness to commit whatever resources it takes to fulfill the mission.'' Lugar said he wants ``authorization for the president to act'' and said he was concerned that otherwise, war could break out because Saddam misunderstood U.S. resolve. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell declared that Bush has no authority - ``none whatsoever'' - under the Constitution to commit U.S. forces to war without prior authorization from Congress. But he also said Bush is using the latest troop buildup as a threat, which does not require congressional approval. A special session of Congress would be justified only if Bush makes a decision to go to war, Mitchell said. ``Obviously no one wishes to conduct a session of Congress without a clearly defined purpose,'' he said after a closed-door Democratic caucus meeting dominated by discussion of the gulf. But he added that Bush's reasons for the new deployment need to be better explained. Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., said, ``My sense is a special session serves no useful purpose. Without hearing the administration's policy, we would be debating in a vacuum.'' Fitzwater said the president believes he has consulted sufficiently with members of Congress and will continue to do so. Fitzwater also dismissed public opinion polls showing declining public support for Bush's Persian Gulf policy, saying, ``You can't always make policy by the polls.'' Asked about Lugar's call for a special session, Fitzwater said, ``The question he raises about a declaration of war is hypothetical at this point ... It presupposes military action ... a war that we hope will not occur.'' Normally, when Congress adjourns for the year it can be called back into session only by the president. However, anticipating developments in the gulf, lawmakers this year gave their own leaders authority to call them back in the adjournment resolution passed as Congress left town on Oct. 28. Bush announced last week he was ordering a massive buildup of forces in the Persian Gulf to permit offensive operations if necessary to force Saddam's withdrawal from Kuwait. There are currently about 230,000 U.S. troops in and around Saudi Arabia and an additional 200,000 are expected. Dole, in an interview, said obtaining congressional support for the Persian Gulf policy should help build a consensus among the public for U.S. actions and quiet domestic critics of Bush's continued deployment of troops. ``I think it ought to be put up to the Congress - put up or shut up. And if they say no, well then, they say no. And then the president has to decide whether to go it alone,'' the Kansas Republican said. Lugar, R-Ind., former chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, told reporters earlier: ``I am ... convinced that so long as Saddam Hussein and the rest of the world has any doubt about the unified resolve of the United States in this matter, the chances for miscalculation and tragic mistakes loom much too large.'' ``I think the president must lay out now to the nation and the Congress specifically what our aims are,'' he said. Lugar said he purposely had avoided using the phrase ``declaration of war'' or mentioning the 1973 War Powers Act. Asked whether reporters could accurately portray him as wanting a declaration of war without calling it that, Lugar replied, ``That is correct.'' ``What we really want is authorization for the president to act,'' he said. Lugar said his worst fear is that war could break out because Saddam misunderstands the U.S. resolve. Lugar said he is concerned there has been ``an erosion around the edges'' among allies for support of U.S. policy in the Gulf. While he finds no erosion of support among his constituents, Lugar said, ``There is a desire to know where we are there ... They almost are left to their imaginations.'' After spelling out U.S. goals, Lugar said, Bush ``must call for a session of the Congress and set a date for the return of the Congress to debate these issues and vote - affirmatively, I would presume - so that we have authorization for what is required,'' Lugar said on NBC's ``Today'' show. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, agreed that ``the Congress should be involved here.'' Bush ``has made a fundamental change in policy'' in ordering the additional troops to the Persian Gulf, Nunn said on the same program. ``He now is giving the military the role of liberating the country of Kuwait.'' ``If there ever is a casebook example of the constitutional power of Congress to declare war, this is it,'' Nunn said. The War Powers Act requires presidential consultation with Congress and puts limits on troop deployments without direct congressional authorization if troops are fighting or under imminent threat of hostilities. Also today, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, briefed Nunn and Sen. John Warner of Virginia, ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee. Nunn said after the closed-door, Capitol Hill session that the lawmakers went through a list of country after country in the coalition against Iraq and questioned each one's level of involvement. Members of Congress have wondered why Egypt, which promised to deploy a second military division this past summer, has not done so and why only a limited number of Kuwaiti forces are involved.

DOC.HEAD: Mitchell, Ford Elected to Democratic Leadership Posts
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Senate Democrats elected Majority Leader George Mitchell to a second term today while Wendell Ford was chosen unanimously for the No. 2 job in the Democratic leadership ranks. Mitchell, of Maine, had no oppositio among the Senate's 56 Democrats. Ford was chosen assistant majority leader after Sen. David Pryor of Arkansas, who had considered challenging him, abandoned that plan and was re-elected as secretary to the Democratic conference. Ford, of Kentucky, will replace Alan Cranston of California, who earlier said he would not seek re-election to the Senate in 1992. On the other side of the aisle, Sen. Thad Cochran of Mississippi was mounting a challenge against Sen. John Chafee of Rhode Island, the incumbent chairman of the Senate Republican Conference, the No. 3 GOP job. Like Mitchell, Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas had no opposition for re-election. Republicans were caucusing later in the day to select their leadership team. In addition to the re-election of Mitchell and Pryor and the elevation of Ford to the leadership job, the Democrats also re-elected Sen. Alan Dixon of Illinois as chief deputy whip and Thomas Daschle of South Dakota as chairman of the Democratic Policy Committee. They also elected Sen. Charles Robb of Virginia to head Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. All votes were unanimous, Mitchell said. Democrats now hold 56 of the 100 Senate seats. Mitchell described Ford as a ``close friend'' and the new No. 2 leader told reporters he would work closely with the Maine Democrat, noting that ``1992 will be a critical election year, as we all know.'' Ford, 62, who is up for re-election in 1992, has been serving as chairman of the Senate Rules Committee. He has long coveted the job that Cranston is vacating. Cranston, in announcing last week that he would not run for re-election to the Senate, said he was suffering from prostate cancer and would relinquish his leadership post. Ford is more conservative than Cranston, and consumer activist Ralph Nader said that means liberals will have to fight harder to push their agenda in the Senate. ``He's pro-tobacco, pro-nuclear, lukewarm on consumers and not very good on the environment,'' Nader said of Ford. He said the election of party leaders is crucial because ``you get a guy up high in the leadership, and it's very important during those crunch times at the end of a session as to whether you can get legislation out.'' Cochran would present a more conservative image in the No. 3 Senate Republican job. He was rated 94 out of 100 by the American Conservative Union in a ranking of senators on several key votes through last August, compared with Chafee's 38 rating. Bob Billings, executive director of the ACU, said he thought Cochran ``would be a little more aggressive'' than Chafee in looking out for conservative interests in the Senate. Cochran was re-elected to his third term in the Senate last week after having served in the House from 1973-78. His effort to win a leadership position comes amid mounting conservative worries about the loss of Sens. James McClure, William Armstrong and Gordon Humphrey, three conservative Republicans who did not seek re-election. ``I think Chafee has been somebody that the conservatives have tolerated for a long period of time,'' said Republican political consultant Tom Edmonds. ``I think conservatives have been on hold for the last two years to wait and see what kind of leadership was coming out of the White House.'' But Stuart Rothenberg, editor of The Political Report, a newsletter, said he wasn't sure whether the contest for the No. 3 GOP leadership post was about ideology. ``A lot of this has to do with personal campaigning for (leadership) office,'' he said. ``It says more about the discussions Republicans have among one another. I'd have trouble portraying it as merely a right-vs.-left struggle for the heart of the party.''

DOC.HEAD: Escapee's Fiance Ordered Back to the United States
DOC.TEXT: The man who fled with convicted murderer Lawrencia ``Bambi'' Bembenek to Canada was ordered Tuesday deported back to the United States, authorities said. An adjudicator for the Canadian Immigration Commission in Thunder Bay ruled that Dominic Gugliatto had worked in Canada without authorization, thereby he ``ceased to be a visitor,'' said Steve Csik, a representative of the Minister of Employment and Immigration. Csik presented the case to Adjudicator Bob Murrant during an hour-long hearing Tuesday at the Thunder Bay Jail. Gugliatto will be turned over to authorities at a port of entry in Minneapolis but officials have yet to set a timetable of when that would occur. Once back in the United States, Gugliatto will face charges of aiding and abetting Bembenek's escape in Fond du Lac, which is in southeastern Wisconsin. Ms. Bembenek, a former model, Milwaukee police officer and Playboy club waitress, created a media sensation when she escaped from the Taycheedah Correctional Institution on July 15. Canadian police captured her with Gugliatto, her fiance, on Oct. 17. The 32-year-old Ms. Bembenek was sentenced to life in prison for the 1981 murder of her former husband's ex-wife. An immigration inquiry for Ms. Bembenek continues later this month in Thunder Bay, Csik said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Will Sign Anti-Crime Bill
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, who has attacked the Democratic-controlled Congress as soft on crime, will sign the anti-crime bill lawmakers sent to him, the White House said Tuesday. Bush, in recent campaign speeches to bolster Republican candidates, often accused the Democrats of ``choking'' his anti-crime package. But his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said the president would sign the congressional version, a stripped-down package that avoided fights over such contentious issues as the death penalty and a ban on assault weapons. ``We think it should have gone further,'' Fitzwater said. ``They left out some key provisions that we though should have been included.'' The House and Senate cut major provisions from the legislation that Bush had sought as a way of making the measure more acceptable. That included a provision to permit use of the death penalty for new categories of federal crimes. The bill toughens penalties for certain white-collar crimes including a possible life prison term in some cases involving fraud by savings and loan officials. It also increases penalties for offenses committed against children and, for the first time, makes possession of child pornography a federal offense.

DOC.HEAD: Flashback on Beirut's Unification Record
DOC.TEXT: The government effort to reunite Beirut has kindled hope and skepticism about peace prospects in Lebanon after 15{ years of civil war. Optimists contend the new attempt is the first since the war started in 1975 to be part of a comprehensive peace accord sponsored by the Arab League and backed by the U.N. Security Council. ``Never before has there been such an international consensus to resolve the Lebanese conflict,'' said Christian warlord Elie Hobeika. ``The Syrian army is dead serious this time to help Lebanese troops smother any defiance by any militia,'' said Hobeika, a staunch ally of Syria. Pessimists argue the two previous bids to unite Beirut collapsed in renewed warfare despite the presence of the Syrian army in 1976 and an international peacekeeping force in 1984. ``We hope it will work this time, but frankly what guarantees do we really have that history won't repeat itself?'' said a commentary broadcast by Beirut's Voice of the People radio station. President Elias Hrawi's government has given the eight major Moslem and Christian militias 10 days beginning last Saturday to evacuate Beirut and its suburbs with their weapons. All militia commands have publicly pledged to meet the Monday deadline. Hrawi's troops then are scheduled to conduct a house-to-house search for weapons that might have been left in secret hideouts. The militia pullout is a key element in the peace plan, which was brokered by the Arab League and approved by the Lebanese parliament in a session held in the Saudi town of Taif in September 1988. The plan provides for creating a militia-free ``greater Beirut'' as a first step toward restoring government authority over all Lebanon's territory. It also gives the Moslem majority of 55 percent an equal share of power with the Christians, who dominated the government, army, parliament and judiciary since Lebanon gained independence from France in 1943. Despite the militia pullout, Hrawi faces the tough task of getting the private armies to disarm. Also, sectarian suspicions run deep and not all the warlords are happy about the even distribution of power. The 200,000-strong Druse Moslems, for instance, fear the larger sects, like the 1.2 million-strong Shiites. The Shiites insist that as the biggest sect in Lebanon they should have a share of power befitting their numbers rather than be treated the same as other sects. Many among the Maronite Catholics, the main Christian sect, deeply resent the Syrians and their allies. The peace accord stalled, but it was revitalized when the Syrian army teamed up with Hrawi's troops to crush Christian Gen. Michel Aoun's mutiny in Lebanon's Christian heartland Oct. 13. The Syrian army entered Lebanon as peace enforcers in July 1976 at the request of Christian leaders, who were losing the war to the Moslems and their Palestinian guerrilla allies. The Arab League later mandated Syria's intervention, stating that it had prevented the emergence of a PLO-controlled government in Lebanon that would have provoked Israel to attack its northern neighbor. The Syrians then dismantled the Green Line that had split Beirut into Moslem and Christian sectors. All militias were disbanded and there were much-publicized raids on their arms hideouts. Newspaper pictures showed senior Syrian officers alongside heaps of confiscated weapons. Beirut's honeymoon lasted 26 months. The Christians, resenting the Syrians' high-handedness in their neighborhoods, took up arms to drive them out. When the Syrians withdrew from the Christian zone in September 1978 after a 100-day war, the Green Line was restored and Christian and Moslem militias were again at each other's throats. New alliances were forged. Right-wing Christians, struggling to maintain their Western ties, aligned themselves with Israel. Left-leaning Moslems and Palestinians, fighting for an Arab identity, sided with Syria. The Israeli army invaded Lebanon in June 1982 to rout Yasser Arafat's guerrillas from their main Middle East power base. In August that year, Israeli-backed Christian militia chieftain Bashir Gemayel was elected president of Lebanon only to be killed in a bomb blast three weeks later. His vengeful militiamen infiltrated Beirut's Sabra and Chatilla Palestinian refugee camps, which were surrounded by invading Israeli troops, and massacred hundreds. Outrage over the atrocities prompted the West to dispatch a multinational force of U.S. Marines, French foreign legionnaires, Italian Bersaglieri soldiers and British paratroopers to keep peace in Beirut. In December 1982, Beirut's demarcation line was again dismantled by the western peacekeepers and the city was reunited anew. The 5,800-strong Western force angered the Moslems by helping the mainly Christian Lebanese army establish control in their zone of the capital. On April 15, 1983, a suicide bomber drove an explosives-packed van into the U.S. Embassy compound in Moslem west Beirut and detonated it, killing more than 60 people, including 17 Americans. On Oct. 23 the same year the U.S. Marine base at Beirut Airport and the French legionnaires headquarters in the city were simultaneously truck-bombed, killing 241 American servicemen and 59 Frenchmen. The attacks were the beginning of pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem terror. Waves of gunpoint kidnappings followed, driving most Westerners and their embassies out of Beirut's Moslem sector. On Feb. 6, 1984, Moslem militiamen again took to the streets and drove the mainly Christian army under former president Amin Gemayel out of the Moslem sector. The multinational force fled, ending a 17-month unification experiment. The Green Line was re-established until Hrawi's government dismantled it again last month. ``I think it's more than a prolonged truce but probably not a lasting peace this time. I dare not be that optimistic,'' said Gamil Kassem, a Moslem pharmacist.

DOC.HEAD: State Employee's Work Saving Suggestion Costs Him His Job
DOC.TEXT: A state clerk's suggestion to use a machine to count pages may win him $10,000, but it already has cost him his job. George Arroyos of Georgetown is one of seven finalists for the first prize in the governor's Productivity Suggestion Awards. The winners are to be announced Thursday. His entry explained a way to save money for the Texas Workers Compensation Commission. But the money saved was his own $10,428-a-year salary. ``In only four months, I succeeded in eliminating my job,'' he said, laughing. Arroyos said he applied for the job when he graduated from Angelo State College. ``I got hired as a mail opener and page counter,'' he said. ``Whenever anyone needs copies of cases on file, (the agency) has to print up the copies. My job was to count the number of pages reproduced and then submit the bill.'' He said he counted so many pages he thought, ``There has to be a better way of doing this.''' After checking several copier services, Arroyos discovered a $6 page counter that attaches to most copying machines. Was he afraid he would lose his job? ``The thought did briefly cross my mind,'' he said. ``But then I thought that if the state saw me as an individual who cared enough about the taxpayers to suggest eliminating his own job, then there might be room for me elsewhere.'' Arroyos was assigned to other duties at the agency before he resigned to take a job as a probation officer.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Some mornings, President Bush leads 645 elementary pupils and their teachers in the Pledge of Allegiance. ``Good morning to all the students and teachers in school today. This is George Bush, president of the United States,'' Bush tells students at Lapel Elementary School. The president was among about 35 celebrities principal Jerry R. Kemerly asked to make tape-recorded messages to lead the pledge. Kemerly sent out the requests with blank cassette tapes in September and has received six responses. Vice President Dan Quayle, an Indiana native, hasn't responded to his request, Kemerly said. ``I thought it would mean more if the children heard from influential people or celebrities or athletes,'' he said. The school also received tapes from Purdue University basketball coach Gene Keady, Rep. Dan Burton, R-Ind., and former Brooklyn Dodger Carl Erskine, now a bank president in Anderson. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Actor Tom Selleck, one of the stars of ``Three Men And a Baby'' and its soon to be released sequel, ``Three Men And a Little Lady,'' says he has a wish list of directors he would like to work with. Selleck said in an interview to be broadcast Thursday on the television show ``Personalities'' that he wants to work with Woody Allen, Martin Scorcese, Barry Levinson, Sydney Pollack and Peter Weir. But he says he hasn't been approached by any of them. ``There are a lot of directors I'd like to work with that haven't exactly rung my phone off the hook,'' he said. He says he would be gladly play a small part for a chance to work with one of the directors. ``Some of the best roles are smaller roles and supporting roles,'' Selleck says. ``I'd play a waiter in a lot of movies.'' --- BERKELEY, Calif. (AP) - Former Black Panther leader Eldridge Cleaver paid $500 to retrieve a set of documents he says ``will tell the story that hasn't been told,'' about the now-defunct militant group. Cartons of Cleaver's books, files and other belongings were nearly sold by the AAAAA Rent-A-Space company last month for $25. Cleaver, 55, owed more than $900 in overdue rental fees. But the documents were returned to Cleaver on Monday after he agreed to pay the storage company $500. ``This is the most comprehensive collection in private hands of what the Black Panther Party was up to,'' Cleaver said. ``This will tell the story that hasn't been told ... and will be a vindication of a lot of slander and lies that have been told about me personally,'' he said. Cleaver, one of the founders of the Oakland-based Black Panthers in 1966, said the items included photographs, papers and pamphlets documenting the group's activities between 1966 and 1975. Cleaver said he will donate them to the Bancroft Library at the University of California at Berkeley. --- CRYSTAL SPRINGS, Miss. (AP) - Country music singer Tom T. Hall visited this town of about 5,000 to help comfort friends and relatives of soldiers in the 162nd Military Police Co., sent to Saudi Arabia last month. The Nashville Network's program ``Nashville Now'' sent Hall to the tiny community just south of Jackson after receiving a letter from resident Rose Beazley. ``I just told `Nashville Now' that a lot of our men were leaving,'' Beazley said, adding that many of the 127 soldiers, including her brother-in-law, had o leave young children behind. Hall hosted an 8-minute segment about Crystal Springs, which was broadcast nationally Monday on the cable network. Hundreds of people crowded into downtown, some waving signs and shouting messages to their soldiers. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Jilly Rizzo, Frank Sinatra's former personal road manager, won't go to prison on several bank-fraud convictions because he is too old and too sick, a judge said Tuesday. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein sentenced Rizzo, 73, to five years on each count, but immediately suspended the sentences and waived thousands of dollars in fines. Rizzo, of Rancho Mirage, Calif., and five other men were convicted in April of operating a scam that led to the 1985 collapse of Flushing Federal Savings and Loan Association. Rizzo has maintained his innocence, saying he was manipulated by con artists seeking to capitalize on his relationship with Sinatra. ``The judge was very fair,'' Rizzo said after the sentencing. The lawyer said Rizzo has a degenerative back disorder and problems with his knees.

DOC.HEAD: Classmates Plant Oak, Name Gym for Stormie
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Paulette Lane...', to CORRECT day of tree planting to Monday sted Sunday.
DOC.TEXT: More than 900 students held a rally today for classmate Stormie Jones, the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, who died at the age of 13. ``Stormie would want all of us to remember her for who she was,'' said Chere Bourland, also 13, who knew Stormie for two years. ``And I think what Stormie wanted us to learn from her is to be proud of what we have, whether we have everything we want or not, and be proud that you are well and alive.'' She was answered by a deafening roar from the 940 students in grades 6-8 at Brewer Middle School in this Fort Worth suburb. Stormie died Sunday at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh. Lab tests to determine what caused her sudden death will take up to two weeks to complete. Paulette Lane, the school's vice principal, said a live oak tree was planted Monday in front of the school in Stormie's remembrance. The flag flew at half-staff at Brewer, which Stormie attended for a few weeks in the fall before being forced home by medical problems. Students voted to name the gymnasium after Stormie. The student council also decided to hang a portrait of the seventh-grader in the hall. ``They decided to dedicate the school yearbook to her, to collect donations all week for her medical bills instead of sending flowers,'' said student council sponsor Connie Massey. A marker will be added where the oak was planted in front of the school, Principal Homer Dear said. ``She liked to do things for other people,'' said Crystal Millikan, 13, Stormie's best fried. ``If you felt bad, she would make your day by saying something funny to cheer you up or by giving a gift and saying, `I love you.''' ``She was always happy and outgoing,'' said Steven Beam, 12. ``She never made fun of anybody.'' Stormie was 6 when she became the first person to receive a transplanted heart and liver at the same time. She received a second liver transplant in February. Stormie on Saturday night was flown with a sore throat and high fever to the Pittsburgh hospital, which had performed the transplants. Her condition deteriorated rapidly. Dr. Jorge Reyes, staff physician at Children's Hospital, said preliminary autopsy results were inconclusive.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Association Publishes Comic Book On Clean Water
DOC.TEXT: A new comic book telling school children about the importance of abundant, clean water was introduced Tuesday by the Soil and Water Conservation Society. The 16-page, full-color cartoon booklet, ``Water in Your Hands,'' is the latest in a series of educational booklets by the association that deals with environmental problems. In the booklet, sixth graders Martin and Heidi meet a character named Fresh Water, who takes them on a global tour, explaining water and its importance. Problems of pollution, erosion, acid rain and scarcity are shown. The non-profit association, which has its headquarters in Ankeny, Iowa, said it has distributed more than 25 million educational booklets since the program began in 1955. A free brochure describing all of the association's materials, including the latest, is available from: SWCS, 7515 N.E. Ankeny Road, Ankeny, Iowa 50021-9764. Telephone 515 289-2331.

DOC.HEAD: Marijuana Scented Cash Leads to Drug Seizure
DOC.TEXT: The pungent odor of marijuana wafting through a bank in this Sacramento suburb led to the arrest of a physician and his wife on suspicion of selling the drug out of their home. Roseville police Lt. Joel Neves said Monday that the aroma came from a small bundle of cash that was traced to Ann Patwell, 32, and her husband, Wayne Patwell, 34. The money had been deposited Wednesday, Neves said. Officers executed a search warrant at the Patwell home in nearby Rocklin and found nearly a hundred sandwich bags filled with marijuana, worth about $10,000, authorities said. A Dec. 5 arraignment was set for the couple.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Says Marines Will Hold Assault Exercise
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Marines will conduct their first amphibious assault exercise in Saudi Arabia since being deployed to the Persian Gulf, the Pentagon said Tuesday. Defense Department spokesman Pete Williams declined to say where in Saudi Arabia the exercise would be held or when it would start. The Washington Times reported that the exercise would be 10 miles from Iraqi-occupied Kuwait and quoted unnamed U.S. officials as saying it was ``provocative'' to hold the maneuvers that close to the border. ``I don't see how you could in any way describe them as provocative,'' Williams said about the maneuver. ``This is Saudi sovereign territory. It isn't like parts of the country have already been red-lined away. It's all Saudi Arabia that we are talking about.'' He said amphibious exercises were an essential part of Marine training and that two had been conducted since U.S. forces were sent to the gulf in response to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Those exercises were held in Oman, farther from the Kuwait border. Williams said more than one of the armed services would be involved in the exercise and there other countries might be involved. He said details would be announced later in the week.

DOC.HEAD: US Warship Fires Warning Shots At Sudanese Freighter
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. warship fired warning shots across the bow of a Sudanese freighter last week and sent men aboard when it refused to stop, but the vessel was empty and was allowed to proceed, the Pentagon said Tuesday. Spokesman Pete Williams said the cargo ship Umdurman was intercepted in the northern Red Sea on Thursday by the Greek frigate Elli as part of enforcement of the embargo on shipments to Iraq. When the Umdurman did not respond to an order to stop, the Greek frigate fired warning shots. The Sudanese vessel still did not stop. The Elli was then joined by the Spanish frigate Cazadora and the U.S. guided missile cruiser Philippine Sea. The Philippine Sea fired 50-caliber and 5-inch shots across the Umdurman's bow. Williams said he did not know how many. The Umdurman was then boarded by helicopter. The boarding party was joined by additional personnel from the Elli and the Philippine Sea. Williams said the Sudanese vessel was allowed to proceed after it was found to be empty. He said he did not know why the vessel's captain failed to stop. Williams said there have been 3,592 intercepts since the embargo was imposed in August. There have been 412 boardings, and 16 ships have been diverted.

DOC.HEAD: Mother, Daughter Give Birth One Day Apart
DOC.TEXT: In one weekend, a 43-year-old woman became a mother for the third time and a grandmother for the first time. Connie Jackson and her 21-year-old daughter, Reena Bochner, delivered babies one day apart at Kaiser Hospital. Jackson and Bochner were in adjoining rooms. ``I've been here 10 years and this has never happened,'' said hospital spokeswoman Mary Jane Watt. ``I think it's a happy coincidence.'' Jackson delivered a month early, giving birth Saturday to Josette, a 4-pound, 14-ounce girl. On Sunday, Bochner delivered 6-pound Mason. ``Having another daughter makes me feel young,'' Jackson said. ``And having a grandson makes me feel wonderful.''

DOC.HEAD: Claims Deadline Extended
DOC.TEXT: The deadline for filing claims under the National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program has been extended, federal officials said Tuesday. Congress moved the deadline to Jan. 31 for claimants injured on or before Oct. 1, 1988. The earlier deadline had been Oct. 1, 1990. Those who miss the deadline may pursue their claims in civil court, but the federal program was set up as a faster, less expensive procedure. The program pays compensation for vaccine-related injuries, requiring petitioners to prove only that the injury is related to a vaccine, not that the manufacturer of the vaccine was at fault. It covers the diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis vaccine; the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine; the oral polio vaccine; and the inactivated polio vaccine, said the Department of Health and Human Services. Claims for injuries that occurred after Oct. 1, 1988, must be filed by deadlines stipulated in the National Childhood Injury Act. The amount of compensation is determined by a U.S. Claims Court based on the needs of the injured person and the extent of the injury. The maximum death benefit is $250,000. Information about how to file a petition may be obtained from the U.S. Claims court, 717 Madison Place N.W., Washington, D.C., 20005. The department's Health Resources and Services Administration toll-free hotline is 800-338-2382.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Courageous, Visionary, NATO's Top General Says
With AM-Soviet-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: NATO's supreme allied commander in Europe praised Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Tuesday as a courageous man of vision, but said he still had some concerns about Soviet military might. U.S. Gen. John R. Galvin told a news conference he was optimistic Gorbachev's reforms would succeed, and said he received indications Soviet military production was easing. Both Galvin and Norwegian Gen. Vigleik Eide, chairman of NATO's military committee, said they were confident a treaty reducing conventional forces in Europe would be signed in Paris later this month, and that it would form the basis for further cuts. Galvin said after meeting Gorbachev on Tuesday: ``I came away from that feeling that I had seen a man of courage and a man of vision.'' ``There is no doubt that the road ahead for the Soviet Union is rocky and difficult, but I personally think, for what that's worth, that it's the right road,'' Galvin said. ``I'm upbeat. I'm optimistic.'' Galvin and Eide arrived in the Soviet Union on Sunday, guests of Defense Minister Dmitri Yazov. It was the first such visit by high-ranking military officials of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``Our presence here must be seen as a clear demonstration of the changing times,'' Eide said. He said the two generals had ``very open and productive conversations'' with their Soviet counterparts. Eide refused to comment on reports of a last-minute hitch in negotiations for the conventional forces treaty, scheduled to be signed by 22 nations on Nov. 19. ``We know that there have been some last-minute negotiations,'' he said. ``That is normal and that should be expected. I am confident, and I also sense the feeling here, that we will have a (conventional forces) agreement signed in a few days time.'' Galvin, asked whether Soviet tanks and other heavy arms have been moved east across the Ural Mountains out of reach of the European treaty, said he was concerned about such reports but not sufficiently to ``raise enough flags'' to scuttle the treaty. ``I have been provided ... with some interesting and in my view partially satisfying answers,'' he said. Galvin also said he received ``indications'' from Soviet officials that production of military equipment was decreasing. ``I see some important changes here in terms of the possible turndown of production and I think it is what's going to happen,'' he said. ``I think there will still be enough production in the Soviet Union to provide for a high-quality force. ... I am concerned with the overall size even after (the agreement).'' Eide said there was broad East-West agreement to resume conventional arms control talks in Vienna after the conventional forces treaty was signed, aimed at ``deeper cuts in the present equipment categories, maybe identifying other categories and also ... the question of manpower.'' The treaty would limit the number of tanks, artillery pieces, armored combat vehicles, aircraft and helicopters that NATO and the Warsaw Pact could maintain in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Responds to Chinese Ship in Trouble Northwest of Hawaii
DOC.TEXT: A Coast Guard cutter was en route Tuesday to a 635-foot Chinese freighter taking on water in an area of shoals about 400 miles northwest of Honolulu. The Mei Gui Hai, with a crew of 39 and 39,000 pounds of barium sulfate, had three hull fractures and had been taking on water for seven days, said Chief Ed Moreth at the headquarters of the 17th Coast Guard District in Juneau. The 180-foot buoy tender Firebush, which was on its way back to Alaska after training exercises in Hawaii, was diverted Monday to help the ship at French Frigate Shoals, about 420 miles northwest of Honolulu, the Coast Guard said. It was expected to reach the scene Wednesday. A Honolulu salvage tug, the Tillamook, and the freighter Lucky Field were standing by near the Chinese vessel in case their help was needed, said Coast Guard Lt. Kent Youel in Honolulu. It was not immediately know where the Mei Gui Hai was bound when it began taking on water, or its home port. Its cargo is a powdered mineral with various uses, including paper coatings, plastics and linoleum. It also is used as a contrast medium for X-rays. The vessel anchored in a shelter near the shoals to escape bad weather, officials said. ``They were experiencing up to 35 knot winds, gusting to 40,'' said Youel. ``They tucked in to get out of the weather and to make some repairs.'' There was no indication that the ship had leaked any of its load, Youel said. He did not know the cause of the hull fractures, and said pump crews from the Tillamook were keeping up with flooding. When the weather improves, the Chinese ship will leave the protection of the shoals and head for Honolulu, Youel said.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Chief to Make First Trip to Moscow
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank said Tuesday its president will visit the Soviet Union, the first such trip in the bank's 45-year history. Barber Conable, who leaves Wednesday, will spend two days in Moscow to study the possibility of allowing the Soviet Union to become a member of the World Bank. The Soviet Union is one of the few countries that doesn't belong to the 154-member bank and its sister organization, the International Monetary Fund. The United States, which has the largest voting power in the bank, has opposed Soviet membership. Some have questioned whether the Soviet Union will remain a united country, with a single currency and one central bank. The World Bank lends more than $21 billion a year to the Third World, but the Soviet Union gets nothing. ``The talks are expected to include a discussion of the Soviet request for technical assistance and issues relating to the possibility of the Soviet Union joining the World Bank,'' the World Bank said in a statement announcing Conable's trip. Conable, the statement said, will explore ways that the bank can help the Soviets move toward a market economy. Conable will meet with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and other leaders. He was invited by Viktor V. Gerashchenko, chairman of the State Bank of the USSR. Gerashchenko led the Soviet delegation that attended the annual joint meetings in September of the bank and the IMF. The bank, the IMF and two other international organizations are making a joint study of the Soviet economy. IMF manging director Michel Camdessus already has visited Moscow. China has been one of the bank's biggest borrowers, getting about $2 billion a year until the suppression of the movement for democracy in June 1989. Since then the United States has said loans should go only for basic human needs and the total has been considerably smaller - $865 million the past 16 months.

DOC.HEAD: DOE Asserts It Has Power To Operate Shoreham Nuclear Plant
DOC.TEXT: The secretary of energy has the authority to operate New York's inactive Shoreham nuclear power plant in the event of an energy emergency, the department contends in a brief filed with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The DOE gave no indication that it intended to try to employ this authority. The department did not immediately return a phone call Tuesday seeking comment. ``Obviously, the use of this authority is one of the options available to the secretary depending on the course of events both in the Middle East and in this country as those events affect the local, regional or national energy supply and security,'' DOE said in a brief filed Nov. 9. Its definition of energy emergency included ``sudden increases in consumer demand (and) inability to obtain adequate amounts of fuel.'' Joseph McDonnell, a spokesman for the Long Island Lighting Co., which built Shoreham, said Tuesday it was ``highly debatable whether the federal government has the authority to order the operation of the Shoreham plant.'' The statutes the DOE has cited ``never contemplated a situation where a state government had decided to close the plant down,'' McDonnell said from Hicksville, N.Y. LILCO has agreed never to operate Shoreham and to sell the plant for a symbolic $1 to New York state. The state plans to decommission the plant and find some means to replace the 800 megawatts of energy Shoreham could have generated. The deal capped years of bitter debate before the NRC. But after George Bush was elected president, the Energy Department began a public relations campaign to stop Shoreham's decommissioning. Energy Secretary James Watkins asked that Shoreham be kept intact and ready to operate, on the assumption that public opinion would eventually turn in favor of the plant.

Before committing U.S. troops to battle against Iraq, President Bush must do a better job convincing the American people of the need for a Persian Gulf war, political analysts say. ``I don't think we've done a very good job in the administration of explaining to the American people in depth what this is all about,'' said Lance Tarrance, a Republican pollster based in Texas. ``We learned from Vietnam that Americans have to be convinced and sold on a rationale for our involvement,'' said Neil Newhouse, a pollster with the Republican firm headed by Richard Wirthlin. War worries swept Washington the past week after Bush announced a substantial increase in the U.S. military presence in the Persian Gulf. The announcement also triggered speculation on the impact that hostilities would have on the 1992 presidential election. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Sen. Wendell Ford seems assured of the No. 2 spot in the Democratic leadership as the two parties organize in the Senate for the start of the 102nd Congress in January. The way was cleared for Ford's selection to succeed Sen. Alan Cranston as the Democratic whip after Sen. David Pryor of Arkansas abandoned plans to challenge the Kentucky Democrat, who won election to a third term last week. On the other side of the aisle, Sen. Thad Cochran of Mississippi was mounting a challenge against Sen. John Chafee of Rhode Island, the incumbent chairman of the Senate Republican Conference, at party organizing caucuses scheduled for today. Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell of Maine and Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas had no challengers. Nor was there any opponent for Assistant GOP Leader Alan Simpson of Wyoming. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The Army overcharged its personnel for temporary lodging and diverted the money to projects like the renovation of a VIP house and two custom throw rugs costing $3,600, congressional investigators say. The General Accounting Office, in reviewing the daily fees assessed to soldiers staying at special housing during training, found that from 1985 to 1989, two Army commands amassed more than $70 million from inflated charges assessed against the per diem allowance given soldiers.
