DOC.HEAD: Silicon Valley Firms Resist Recession, But Tighten Up
DOC.TEXT: The economic crisis in the Northeast has stayed out of Silicon Valley so far, defying the doomsayers on Wall Street. But fears of a recession have clearly arrived. Remembering the hard times in 1985 and 1986, when bloated Silicon Valley companies laid off tens of thousands of workers, the operative phrase for most firms here these days is ``tighten up.'' Companies are avoiding unnecessary trips, watching the cost of meals, trimming inventory and work force. Lavish Christmas parties are out. Computer and chip companies in this high-tech mecca have been bracing for a recession for months, although there is still no strong evidence that a major downturn in the electronics business is imminent. Sales overall are up from a year ago, inventories are down, and there are no big layoffs, despite pockets of trouble. Cash is king. Apple Computer Inc. is sitting pretty on a $1 billion hoard - built up from $800 million a year ago - to get through future economic bumps. Apple Chairman John Sculley says the only people who aren't acknowledging an oncoming recession are government economists. He and other Silicon Valley leaders have been preparing for a slowdown by cutting manufacturing and sales costs and lowering prices to attract buyers. ``Entering a recession, it's better to be coming out with more aggressively priced items than high-end items,'' said Apple spokesman Christopher Escher. ``Our newest Macintoshes are positioned well for a tighter economic situation.'' Although fat work forces are out, companies here have been avoiding heavy layoffs. ``Premature layoffs have mostly been a New England phenomenon,'' said Jerry Jordan, chief economist at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. ``Unlike California, that area is really in a serious recession.'' Hewlett-Packard Co. slimmed down a bit, from 95,000 workers to 92,000, so far this year and it continues to cut back by attrition. It also plans to close four extra days with mandatory vacations between Christmas and New Year's Day to save operating costs and remove days off as a liability on its books. National Semiconductor Corp. restructured this summer and cut jobs from 32,000 to 30,000. Advanced Micro Devices Inc. is expected to cut about 1,200 jobs by year's end. In each of those cases, though, the cuts are related to the distinct business conditions impacting the companies. As a whole, the computer and chip industries here are holding off a major downturn. ``In the last couple of months there's been a general tightening,'' said Fred Zieber of Dataquest Inc., a high-tech market research firm in San Jose. ``There's a lot of concern among management about the near-term future because they just don't know what sort of recession there may or may not be. ``It's been more of a management control reaction, more anticipation than reality. The numbers, by and large, don't support the concern.'' Unlike the hard times that have hit the Northeast, especially along the high-tech corridor of Route 128 in Massachusetts, the computer companies here are not heavily dependent upon military or aerospace contracts, which have suffered in recent years. In Silicon Valley, the computer companies focus more on workstations, personal computers and peripherals. One sign that things may get worse came earlier this month when Businessland Inc., a San Jose-based retail firm, reported a $19.8 million loss for its first fiscal quarter and said it would lay off 780 people, or 20 percent of its work force, by year's end. David Norman, Businessland's chief executive officer, attributed the revenue drop to industry price-cutting, new product introductions and sluggish capital equipment spending by corporations. Apple's new lower-priced Macintoshes appear to be selling briskly, and sales are good at Hewlett-Packard, Sun Microsystems Inc. and other computer companies. Sun is expected to receive a boost from the Sparcstation 2 line recently introduced. The graphics workstations, which range in price from $14,995 to $49,995, are far more powerful and versatile than the bestselling Sparcstation 1. Computer chip orders rose modestly through the summer, increasing 9.8 percent in September alone over a year ago. They're expected to keep increasing into next year. ``The statistics at this point do not indicate a recession in the semiconductor industry,'' said Tom Beermann, spokesman for the trade group Semiconductor Industry Association. A recent SIA forecast estimated worldwide chip sales would grow 12.5 percent in 1991, following a year of relatively flat growth from 1989's $48.8 billion to about $49.5 billion this year. If war breaks out in the Middle East, the group estimated chip sales would grow by a more moderate 6.25 percent next year. But those rosy numbers mask a severe drop in sales of memory chips, which are down 18 percent this year, according to Dataquest. The drop there is mostly hurting the Japanese manufacturers who dominate the memory market. Silicon Valley chipmakers who specialize in more advanced devices are benefiting from a 12 percent rise in microprocessor sales, 7 percent in logic chips and 7 percent in analog chips. ``The chip and computer industries may be just fine overall, but that doesn't mean there isn't a lot of pain in a lot of companies,'' said Dataquest's Zieber. ``I think you'll have a tough market for awhile but not one that completely falls apart. If there's a debacle coming, it's not real evident so far.'' Inventories of semiconductors are relatively flat, and inventories of computers are up only slightly, Zieber said. ``By historical standards they're both a little below average, which is good,'' he said. ``If you get too much inventory, then you have to cut back twice as far if a recession sets in.'' Even companies that are flush, such as Intel Corp., maker of the popular chips that act as the brains of International Business Machine Corp.'s personal computers and IBM ``clones,'' are yielding to the economic uncertainties. ``We're looking at critical hires only,'' said Pam Pollace, an Intel spokeswoman. ``We're seeking to be conscientious about internal controls, inventory, spending. We're asking people to avoid unnecessary travel and expenses.'' Intel's earnings remain strong, rising to $172 million in the third quarter from $72 million a year ago. Intel is boosting spending for research and development, from $422 million last year to $600 million this year, Pollace said, ``because in this business you need to continue that to keep moving ahead with the technology.'' Advanced Micro Devices lost $23.7 million in the last two quarters and expects to post another loss in the current quarter. But the company is cautious about laying off workers because it believes its long-term prospects are solid. The company recently completed a $200 million development center and this past week introduced a microprocessor to compete against Intel's hot-selling 80386 microprocessor. ``We've been doing things to react to our own business conditions, which has had the same effect on us as a recession,'' said AMD spokesman John Greenagel. ``AMD has not performed as well as the semiconductor industry as a whole for some time. The actions we've taken we'd have to take regardless of the economic conditions.''

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Title to Swallow Ticor, a Major Competitor
DOC.TEXT: Chicago Title and Trust Co., the largest U.S. title insurer, announced plans to purchase its biggest competitor, Ticor Title Insurance Cos. The merger would create an almost $1 billion per year company. Chicago Title's revenues were about $561 million in 1989 and the Ticor companies' were $408 million, said Joann Shanley, spokeswoman for Ticor's parent Westwood Equities Corp. Chicago Title, a unit of Alleghany Corp. in New York, said Monday the deal is expected to close during the first quarter of 1991, subject to approval by regulators and other conditions. No antitrust or other difficulties were expected to interfere with the purchase, Ms. Shanley said. The deal follows a consolidation trend among title insurers, who check property records and guarantee to buyers and lenders that a seller of property actually owns it. Ticor, once the largest title insurer, has lost money recently, as has the $4 billion industry in general. Price squeezing, claims inflation and sagging real estate markets have contributed to the problems. A previous agreement to buy Ticor by General Motor Corp.'s data processing unit fell apart last month, reportedly because Ticor's problems were worse than anticipated. Ticor is privately owned and doesn't disclose profit and loss figures. But Ms. Shanley acknowledged it lost money in 1989. ``The same would be the case in 1990, especially with the real estate situation the way it is,'' she said. The title insurance industry reported losses on operations of $112 million in 1988 and $154 million in 1989, although investment income cushioned the losses, according to the American Land Title Association. Ticor will become the fourth of the largest 12 companies in the industry to go out of business or be taken over since 1987. Chicago Title's chief executive, Richard P. Toft, last month predicted further consolidations. Toft and other Chicago Title officials declined to discuss any details of the purchase Monday. The Ticor title insurers - Ticor Title Insurance Co. of California, Ticor Title Insurance Co. and New York-based Ticor Title Guarantee Co. - are based in Los Angeles along with Westwood Equities. Westwood also owns Ticor Realty Tax Services, which handles the impound accounts in which taxes are placed and then forwarded to the government when property is sold. TRTS accounted for a bit more than a quarter of Westwood's $549 million in 1989 revenues. It's not being bought by Chicago Title.

DOC.HEAD: Hotel Chain Says It's Restructuring Debt, Halting Payments
DOC.TEXT: Days Inns of America Inc. says it is halting all principal and interest payments until the hotel chain can complete a restructuring of $744 million in debt, much of it in high-yield bonds. Officials of the Atlanta-based company maintained that its day-to-day operations are sound. Days Inns President John D. Snodgrass said he was confident the restructuring could be worked out by early 1991. Snodgrass said the company's debt structure, high interest rates and short amortization schedules, rather than its operations were the cause of problems. ``If you look at the operating side of the company, it's extremely healthy,'' he said. Reliance Group Holdings, which sold the chain to New York-based Tollman-Hundley Hotels in 1989, accumulated much of the debt. The 1,100-unit chain, which marks its 20th anniversary Thursday, said Monday it has not made recent payments of principal and interest related to about $325 million of long-term and short-term obligations. It is paying an average interest rate of 14 percent. The company would not identify its major debt holders but said fewer than 10 own about half of the debt currently in default. There are a total of about 200 debt holders, Snodgrass said. Days Inn said it is working with the major debt holders as well as with an undisclosed New York investment banking firm to restructure the debt. Following the company's announcement Monday, Moody's Investors Service lowered its rating on Days Inns' subordinated debt of about $149 million from CAA to CA. Moody's said the lowering reflected an overcapacity in the lodging industry as well as the economy's slowdown. Snodgrass said the chain's reservations are up 9.5 percent over last year and the company is paying its vendors on a timely basis, within 60 days. The company has franchise agreements for 350 new hotels in the next two years.

DOC.HEAD: Factory Still Makes Vinyl Records
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Michael Hornung is a vinyl romantic. He plays albums at home and keeps a record player in his office. He also has resisted pleas from his 21-year-old son to ``get with it'' and buy a compact disc player. As director of operations at MCA Manufacturing Corp.'s record and tape plant in Gloversville, N.Y., Hornung runs one of the few remaining plants in the country that manufacture vinyl records. ``It's sad to think there may come a day when records are no longer made,'' Hornung said. ``Demand for vinyl has fallen off, but we're still producing it. It's still selling.'' The 37-year-old plant in this old tannery town in upstate New York manufactures cassette tapes and vinyl records for MCA, whose artists include Elton John, Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, Bobby Brown and the Oak Ridge Boys. MCA also owns Motown Records and the jazz-oriented GRP Records label in addition to Universal Pictures and the Universal City Theme Park in California. The company recently purchased Geffen Records in a deal expected to be completed by early next year. The Gloversville plant is the only place in the country where MCA makes vinyl records, which account for 20 percent of music recording sales nationwide, according to Hornung. He said it might be the only place in the country where 45s are still made. Hornung, who's worked at the Gloversville facility for 20 years, believes that records will disappear at some point in his lifetime. ``I think we're getting closer to that point,'' said Mick Borthick, head of production at Chrysalis in New York. Several developments this year seem to indicate that. Chrysalis and PolyGram announced that with a few rare exceptions, all their new releases will be on cassette tape and CD only. Warner-Elektra-Atlantic reported that it will cut out more than 40 percent of its vinyl catalogue. That means 1,205 album titles owned by the conglomerate will no longer be available on records. The Tower Records chain said it will no longer sell 7-inch single records because several major labels won't accept returns on unsold records. ``Record buyers are in the minority,'' said Robert Cohen, manager of the Finyl Vinyl record store in New York. ``Vinyl is becoming a specialty item.'' In 1982, the year before CDs were introduced, manufacturers shipped out 244 million records for sales of $2 billion, according to the Recording Industry Association of America. Last year, manufacturers shipped out only 34 million records for sales of $220 million. By comparison, 207 million CDs were shipped out in 1989 for sales of $2.6 billion, the association said. About 446 million tape cassettes also were sold. ``CDs and cassettes have really taken over,'' Borthick said. He noted that cassette players are favored by youths and most other music lovers have been seduced by the clearer sounds of CDs. Chrysalis, with annual sales of $70 million worldwide, said recent releases by Sinead O'Connor and Billy Idol sold few record albums in this country, slightly more than 1 percent. The rest were CD and cassette sales. ``You can understand why we're not anxious to manufacture records,'' Bothrick said. It's not economical to operate pressing plants when they're only turning out a few records, he said. Merchants said they would rather discontinue records so they could have more room for cassettes and the more expensive CDs. Records account for only 2 percent of sales in the 82-store Record World, so vinyl is being phased out, said Mitch Imber, purchasing director. That's left many feeling that records are being killed off prematurely. ``Manufacturers are looking to remove the option of buying records from consumers,'' said Cohen, of the Finyl Vinyl record store. ``They have abandoned a big segment of the record-buying community in order to push the more expensive CD format.'' Merchants who still want to carry records said return policies and reordering difficulties are putting pressure on them to relent. Cohen said he's charged anytime he returns an album, whether it's defective or not. There's no penalty for cassette and CD returns. Hornung is paying close attention to the changing times. But he said his plant, which distributes tapes and records throughout the Northeast and as far west as Ohio, isn't planning to manufacture CDs. Instead, the Gloversville plant is expanding its tape production capabilities. The facility is the No. 3 producer of tapes in the country, behind Warner-Elektra-Atlantic and CBS Records, Hornung said. ``We've shrunk vinyl operations and expanded into this,'' Hornung said. The factory still makes 7-inch and 12-inch records and will continue to do so as long as there's demand for them, Hornung said. ``Bless them,'' said Cohen, whose store caters to vinyl romantics, especially with hard-to-find records from the 1960s. ``And if we're the last store still selling these 12-inch pieces of black plastic, then that's just fine with me.''

DOC.HEAD: Koala Springs Recalls All Juice-Based Products; Confirms Contamination
DOC.TEXT: Koala Springs International, maker of popular juice-based bottled water products, today recalled all of its beverages from retail shelves and warehouses in the United States. Company president John Chatham said tests revealed ``minute traces of contaminants in some of our product at levels between 11 and 18 parts per billion.'' It did not specify what the contaminants were. The tests were conducted last weekend and today in Tallahassee, Fla., the company said. The levels of contaminants pose no significant health risk to the general public, the company said, adding that it decided to withdraw its product ``so as to avoid any possible concern by retailers or consumers.'' The company ordered retailers and distributors to halt shipment of all Koala Springs juice-based products and to hold supplies in warehouses until further notice. Stores were ordered to remove all stock from retail shelves and return it to warehouses for storage. ``We deeply regret any inconvenience that this action may have caused, but it is the most responsible course of action that we can follow at this time,'' said Chatham in a written statement.

DOC.HEAD: Ad Agency Quits Volvo Account In Wake of Disputed Volvo Ad
By SKIP WOLLENBERG
DOC.TEXT: The carmaker Volvo's advertising agency quit today, saying it was taking responsibility for the bogus commercial depicting a Volvo that resisted the stomping of a big pickup truck while other cars collapsed. Scali McCabe Sloves Inc. said it was resigning as the ad agency for Volvo Cars of North America because of questions raised about the production of the so-called ``Monster Truck'' commercial for the Swedish car. The ad showed a Volvo was the only car left standing a pickup truck with oversized tires ran over a row of cars. It was later discovered the Volvo had been reinforced and the other cars were weakened before the ad was shot. The ad agency's chairman, Marvin Sloves, said in announcing the agency was resigning the account that agency executives had worked for 23 years to establish Volvo as ``one of the most respected and admired brand names in North America.'' As a result, he said felt agency executives wanted to insure that ``our actions in no way diminish the value and reputation of the Volvo name.'' ``To this end it is imperative that we resign and accept ultimate responsibility for what happened. Now is not the time to point fingers at anyone,'' he said. He said it had been established that the issue was ``only the making of this advertisement'' and not the strength or durability of Volvo cars, the integrity of the car company or any previous advertising. A call was placed to Volvo for comment on the development, but it was not immediately returned. Under pressure from the state attorney general of Texas, Volvo announced last week it had pulled the commercial and would run corrective ads because it turned out the Volvo in the ad had been reinforced with steel or wood. At the same time, Volvo admitted that those who made the commercial had removed supports in the other cars in the ads. The automaker, which admitted no wrongdoing in settling the dispute with the attorney general in Texas, said the ad was a dramatization of a 1988 Vermont event and should have stated it was a dramatization. But the commercial carried no such disclaimer. Volvo said the modifications were made to the cars to ensure the crew's safety while making the ad.

DOC.HEAD: Panhandle Eastern Chairman, CEO Quits
DOC.TEXT: Panhandle Eastern Corp. has chosen the former president of a company it acquired as its new chairman and chief executive officer. Dennis R. Hendrix, former president of Texas Eastern Corp., succeeds Philip J. Burguieres, who resigned for unspecified health reasons less than a year after taking the posts. Burguieres, a board member since 1984, had been handpicked by former Panhandle chairman Bob Hunsucker to succeed him when he retired at the end of 1989. Burguieres also is giving up his seat on the board. Neither Burguieres nor Hendrix would comment on the change Monday. Panhandle spokesman James W. Hart Jr. said Burguieres' illness had not responded to medication, but was not life-threatening and was reversible with several months of treatment. During the last year, Burguieres was credited with taking some tough but necessary steps to help Panhandle. He cut capital spending from about $450 million to $250 million and streamlined management of the merged organization, said First Boston analyst John Olson. Burguieres cut the company's annual dividend from $2 to 80 cents a share in July because profits weren't covering the dividend, a move expected to save more than $100 million a year.

DOC.HEAD: Iran, Qatar to Invest $3 Billion On Gas Project
DOC.TEXT: Iran and Qatar will invest $3 billion to tap the offshore Pars gas field, one of the biggest in the world, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported Tuesday. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, quoted a deputy oil minister identified as M. Naimi as saying the joint project would be running by the the end of 1994. The gas reserves lie beneath Iranian and Qatari waters in the Persian Gulf. Naimi said the gas will be exported to Eastern and Western Europe. He said Iran intends to pump the gas through a pipeline it will build through Turkey. Iran, which already sits atop of the world's second largest gas reserves, after the Soviet Union, currently pumps up to 3 billion cubic meters of natural gas to the Soviets a year.

DOC.HEAD: Government Wants To Introduce More Telephone Competition
DOC.TEXT: The government said Tuesday it wants to introduce more competition into Britain's multibillion-dollar telecommunications market and end the control held by giant British Telecom. British Telecommunications PLC, which the government privatized six years ago, controls about 97 percent of the local telephone market. The rest is held by Mercury Communications Ltd. Trade Secretary Peter Lilley outlined to the House of Commons the government's proposal for allowing new players into the local, domestic long distance and international markets. Foreign companies would be allowed to apply for licenses in all three telecommunications categories, the trade department said. The new competitors progressively would be allowed equal access to British Telecom's existing British infrastructure, Lilley said. Lilley also said government price constraints on British Telecom should remain in place until 1993. Under the constraints set by the Office of Telecommunications, the company can raise no more than 4.5 percent below the rate of inflation, which is 10.9 percent. `This country has already benefited from our policies of privatization and competition and because of the U.K.'s lead we are becoming a telecommunications hub for Western Europe,'' Lilley said. ``The government is committed to reinforce this lead and to ensure that consumers have the widest possible services at the most competitive price,'' he said. British Telecom said it welcomed the government's ``general thrust'' for greater competition and choice. But it was disappointed that cable television companies would be allowed to continue their monopoly in providing entertainment services. Lilley said British Telecom would be barred from that market for the next 10 years. British Telecom has 19 million residential and 6 million business customers. It had after-tax profit of 1.54 billion pounds, or $3 billion, in its last fiscal year, on revenue of 12.3 billion pounds ($24 billion). The government invited comment on its plan until Jan 14.

DOC.HEAD: Yields Lower on Bills
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell in Tuesday's auction to their lowest level in more than two years. The Treasury Department sold $10 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.05 percent, down from 7.07 percent last week. Another $10 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.02 percent, down from 7.05 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 6.94 percent on Aug. 8, 1988, and six-month bills averaged 6.99 percent on July 11, 1988. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors - 7.28 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,821.80 and 7.38 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,645.10. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 7.35 percent last week, down from 7.41 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: European Court Approves Ban on Hormones In Cattle Breeding
DOC.TEXT: The European Court of Justice Tuesday approved the European Community's 1985 ban on the use of hormones in cattle breeding. The court ruled Tuesday that the ban was justified to allay health concerns of European consumers, as expressed by the European parliament, the European Economic and Social Committee and various European consumers associations. The Luxembourg court at first voided the European directive, mainly for legal technicalities, and the EC immediately revised its text to comply with the court objections. European producers of pharmaceutical and veterinary products then attacked the ban before the court, claiming there was no scientific evidence the use of hormones was harmful to humans. The 1985 ban led to U.S. trade reprisals. The U.S. government claimed its cattle breeders were losing $100 million worth of exports because of the ban, and slapped tariffs on various European food exports.
